loans.name: John Koileken Ole

texts.en:
John Koileken Ole K. is 44 years old. He is married to Sempeo K. and is the father of four children.

John is a farmer, which he does on his own piece of land. He has been doing this for the last 10 years.

He learned about KADET through a friend, who is already a registered member of KADET, a Kiva partner. This will be his first loan. He is planning to  spend 25,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to plow; 20,000 KES on harrowing; 20,000 KES on seeds; and 15,000 KES on planting his 10 acres of wheat. Wheat has proved to be doing well in the area due to favorable weather conditions and adequate rainfall.

He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming. John's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: For plowing, harrowing, buyings seeds and planting 10 acres of wheat

loans.name: Jacinta Wanjiku Mukundi

texts.en:
Jacinta Wanjiku Mukundi N. is 42 years old. She is married to Wilson and is the mother of four children. 

Jacinta is a farmer on her own piece of land.  She has been farming for the last 10 years.

She learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in her area of residence. This will be her fourth loan. She is planning to spend the 30,000 Kenyan shillings on maize farming; maize has proved to be doing very well due to fertile lands in the area and adequate rainfall. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to rent more land for farming to increase maize production. She also hopes to buy some livestock and start livestock farming.

Her future dream is that she will be able to practice large-scale maize farming. She is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: Maize farming

loans.name: Teule Ene

texts.en:
Teule Ene M. is 52 years old. She is married to Simel M. and is a mother of four children.

Teule is a farmer. For the last eighteen years, she has been farming on her own piece of land.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered members in KADET. This will be her second loan. She is planning to spend twenty thousand shillings to plant more wheat, which normally does well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Teule's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. 

She is a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To plant wheat

loans.name: Noonkishu

texts.en:
Noonkishu N. is 32 years old. She is married to Leuto N. and is a mother of two school-aged children.

Noonkishu is a farmer, a job which she has been doing for the last six years. Her farm is in a productive area. Most of her customers are wholesalers from the city who come to buy the produce and then re-sell it to city residents.

She learned about KADET through an awareness session done by the KADET staff in her area. This will be her second loan. She is planning to buy a new species of potato called "sangi," which research has shown can do very well in the area and produce a higher yield. She hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for produce.

Her hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and have her own farm machinery.

Noonkishu is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To buy a new species of potato

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn H. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 24 years old. Arlyn is single and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Arlyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Arlyn has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Arlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Arlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Arlyn is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Arlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Basilia

texts.es:
La Sra. Basilia C. D. G. es propietaria D. una despensa la cual se encuentra ubicada en su domicilio hace más D. 15 años.
 Se encuentra casada  con el Sr. Víctor, con quien tiene 3 hijos; Víctor José D. 22 años quien estudia Licenciatura en Administración D. Empresas, María Alejandra D. 17 años quien cursa el 3º año D. la media y Anabel D. 9 años D. edad, quien está en la etapa escolar.
La Sra. Basilia comenta que comenzó con su despensa en una pequeña piecita y hoy día ha mejorado bastante ya que con el trabajo D. toda la familia ha logrado aumentar su negocio D. manera muy notable.
Comentó además que día a día  seguirá tratando D. crecer para poder mejorar su calidad D. vida y D. su familia.
El último crédito que retiró lo invirtió en la compra D. mayor cantidad D. mercaderías tales como: harina, arroz, azúcar, fideo, etc. para surtir mucho más su despensa.
texts.en:
Mrs. Basilia C. D. G. is the owner of a small grocery store that she has run out of her home for more than 15 years. She is married to Mr. Victor, with whom she has three children: Víctor José, 22, who is studying for a Bachelor's in Business Administration; María Alejandra, 17, who is studying in her third year of secondary school; and Anabel, 9, who is in primary school. Mrs. Basilia says that she started her store in a very small room but today it is greatly improved; due to the work her whole family has done, they have grown their business remarkably. She also commented that day by day, she will continue trying to grow so that she can improve her and her family's quality of life. She used her last loan to invest in purchasing more goods to stock her store, such as: flour, rice, sugar, noodles, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour, rice, noodles, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is married to an engineer.  They have four children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of her old father.

She sells local gin at her home in Kisaasi and sells to all categories of peoples but on a retail basis. Besides this bar business, she owns a salon in Kisaasi and wants to use this loan to buy more jerry cans of local gin. She has been in this business for two years. Her customers are the neighboring community.  Her business challenges are seasonality and defaulters. She aspires to buy a plot of land.

Gladys resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  She joined MCDT because they loan to women who are in groups with no securities. Her monthly expenses includes food, utility bills and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more jerry cans of local gin

loans.name: Zerpher

texts.en: Zerpher S. is currently in the business of selling fruit such as pears, avocado, passion fruits, etc. and is requesting a loan in order to stock jack fruit and apples to sell. Zeripher is married with four children who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock jack fruit and apples to sell

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en: Aurora D. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old, separated from her spouse and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Aurora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Aurora has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Aurora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Aurora is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Aurora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: O. Madeleine est née en 1976 à Pobè, dans le département du Plateau. Mariée à HOUNGBEDJI Sosthène, un commerçant, Madeleine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Madeleine vit avec sa famille à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Madeleine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Madeleine vend divers produits (sucre, savons, biscuits, huile d'arachide, riz, pâtes alimentaires, lait, etc.) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Madeleine vend en détail du charbon de bois emballé dans des sachets. Madeleine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Madeleine exerce cette activité depuis sept ans et a déjà obtenu quatre crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Madeleine voudrait rehausser davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Madeleine sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un cinquième prêt.
texts.en:
Madeleine O. was born in 1976 in Pobé, in the Plateau department. She is married to Sosthene Houngbedji, an entrepreneur, and is the mother of four children, all of whom attend school. Madeline lives with her family in Djeffa, in the community of Seme-Podji in Benin. The couple takes care of the family expenses jointly. Madeleine did not attend school. In order to support her family, she sells various products (sugar, soaps, cookies, peanut oil, rice, pasta, milk etc) out of her home. In addition, she also sells charcoal retail, in small packs. Madeline stocks up in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this line of business for seven years and obtained four loans from ALIDé in the past, all duly repaid. Madeleine would like to expand her business and better satisfy the customer demand, which is why she is seeking a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various products (peanut oil, rice, pasta, milk, sugar, soap, etc.)

loans.name: Virgincita

texts.en:
From the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental, Virgincita G. is 55 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Virgincita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 3 years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Virgincita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP for the same purpose. Virgincita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en:
Rejoice P. sells plastic plates, cups, and bowls at the shop and requests a loan to stock jugs and cups to sell. Rejoice married a nurse and has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from the business generated by this loan, she wants to extend the floor of her shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock jugs and cups to sell

loans.name: Luna

texts.en:
Luna J. is from the village of Sugbongcogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 36 years old. Luna is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Luna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Luna has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Luna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Luna is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Luna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
Kuña Guapa se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Itá en fecha 18 de marzo de 2009, donde la presidenta del grupo es la Sra. Nancy Narváez, quien se dedica a la venta de joyas de plata.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen.
La Sra. Nancy comenta que las compañeras del comité tienen muchas ganas de trabajar y seguir progresando.
Ella por su parte se dedica  a la venta de joyas de plata, que es una actividad que ella emprendió desde que formo parte del comité. 
Ella expone sus joyas en el salón que tiene en su casa y además visita a mucha gente para aumentar su venta.
Comenta que el ganancia de su actividad ella lo invierte en la mejora continua de su vivienda. 
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de joyas como pulseras, aros, gargantillas, y otros todos en plata.
texts.en:
Kuña Guapa is a group of women founded in the city of Itá on 18 March 2009. The group's president is Nancy Narváez, who sells silver jewellery. All group members assist with fundraising and help each other achieve their goals. Nancy says that the other committee members are keen to work hard and continue to progress. Nancy sells silver jewellery, a business she started since becoming a member of the committee. She exhibits the pieces in a room in her home and also visits people to increase sales. She invests her business benefits in the continuous improvement of her home. She is requesting the loan to buy silver jewellery, including bracelets, earrings and necklaces.

Translated from Spanish by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of silver items: bracelets, earrings, necklaces, rings

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is married to a businessman and they have five children, all of whom go to school. Christine also takes care of additional family members.  She owns a canteen and sells snacks like chapatti, samosas, donuts, and pancakes. She wants to use this loan to buy more baking flour, cooking oil, cow peas, and a bag of charcoal. She has been in this business for five years. Besides this canteen business she also sells firewood at her stall in Natete market. Her customers are the market vendors. She works six days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and transportation of firewood from villages to her place of work. She is aspiring to grow her business and eventually own a big bakery. Christine decided to work with MCDT because of the trustworthy staff. She resides in and owns a two-room house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and cooking ingredients

loans.name: Etiennette

texts.fr: A. Etiennette est née le 17 Avril 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Etiennette est mariée à HOUINSOU Julien et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Etiennette vit avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sème-Podji, depuis une dizaine d'année. Le couple se partage ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Etiennette a fréquenté juste l'école primaire. Depuis huit ans environs, Etiennette mène comme activité, la vente de fagots de bois à son domicile. Etiennette s'approvisionne à ONAB (société de commercialisation de bois au Bénin). Etiennette est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Etiennette désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Etiennette sollicite un cinquième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Etiennette was born on April 17, 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to HOUINSOU Julien and is the mother of three children who are all in school.  She has been living in the Lokokoukoumè district, in the community of Sème-Podji, for about ten years.  The couple share in covering their different family expenses.  Etiennette attended primary school only. For about eight years, she has had a business selling bundles of firewood out of her home.  She gets her supplies at ONAB (a company marketing firewood in Benin).  She is a previous client of ALIDé having already had four loans, which have all been repaid.  Facing the more and more numerous demands of her customers, Etiennette would like to increase her stock of goods and to satisfy her customer further.  For these reasons, she is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bundles of firewood wholesale

loans.name: Blanca

texts.es:
Blanca tiene 36 años de edad y vive en pareja con Jorge de 44 años de edad hace mas de 17 años, tienen tres hijos, una mujer y dos varones en edades escolares.
Ella se dedica en la venta de ropa, dicho negocio empezó después de su vuelta de Buenos Aires  donde trabajaba como empleada doméstica. 
Su pareja es constructor y le ayuda con los gastos del hogar.
Blanca se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir de todo tipo y con los ingresos de dicha actividad ayuda al sustento familiar. 
A pesar de que tiene mucha competencia ella no se queja y afirma que tiene buena clientela ya formada a quienes surte en forma diaria, semanal o mensual. 
El crédito que está solicitando es para la compra de mercaderías para su negocio tales como: jeans, remeras, conjuntos, camperas, buzos, suéter, botas,etc. que traerá en base a los pedidos que le han hecho sus clientes y luego les cobrará en cómodas cuotas.
texts.en:
Blanca is 36 and lives with her partner Jorge, 44, for more than 17 years. They have three children, one girl and two school-aged boys. Blanca works selling clothes; she began this business after her return from Buenos Aires, where she worked as a housekeeper. Her partner is a builder and helps with household expenses. Blanca sells all kinds of clothing and with the income from this activity helps support her family. In spite of having a lot of competition, she doesn’t complain; rather she says that she already has a good customer base to whom she caters daily, weekly or monthly. The loan that she is requesting is for the purchase of business merchandise such as jeans, shirts, suits, jackets, tracksuits, sweaters, boots, etc. that she will supply according to her customers’ requests. Later they will be charged in easy installments.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha Cerone, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Merchandise

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia C. is from the village of Lurugan in Valencia City in the province of Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Amelia is married and has four grown children. To make a living, Amelia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Amelia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years, and she earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Amelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 24,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Amelia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Amelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Orlette

texts.en:
Orlette T. is from the village of Sugbongcogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 20 years old. Orlette is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Orlette owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Orlette has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Orlette joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Orlette is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Orlette from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 30 years old and he is still single.  Samuel owns a motorcycle, which he uses to earn his daily living.  Samuel has been driving a motorcycle for about 6 years and he drives from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day.

Samuel needs to purchase a second motorcycle, which he hopes will increase his daily profits.  To end this, Samuel is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this second motorcycle, Samuel hopes to earn a lot of money, which will be used to create other sources of income.

loans.use: One additional motorcycle

loans.name: Janefa

texts.en:
Janefa S. is in the business of selling bread and groundnut products. She is requesting a loan for the possibility of stocking onions and tomatoes to sell. Janefa has four children and is widowed. With the extra income, she intends to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Vidéhoun

texts.fr: F. H. Vidéhoun est née le 05 Janvier 1947 à Adjohoun dans le département de l'Ouémé. Mariée à GBEGNON Bruno, Vidéhoun est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Vidéhoun s'est installée depuis vingt trois ans environs, au quartier Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Les charges de la famille sont supportées à la fois par Vidéhoun et son mari. Vidéhoun n'est jamais allée à l'école. Depuis près de 15 ans, Vidéhoun  mène comme activité, la vente d'ustensiles de cuisine, de sacs et de chaussures à son domicile. Vidéhoun s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle,Vidéhoun sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit en vue d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire.
texts.en:
Vidéhoun F. H. was born on January 5, 1947 in Adjohoun, in the Ouémé prefecture. She is married to Bruno Gbegnon and is the mother of two children who attend school. Since about 23 years ago, Vidéhoun has been living in the Agblangandan district, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. Vidéhoun and her husband share the responsibility of providing for the family needs. Vidéhoun never attended school. For about 15 years, her line of business has been selling kitchen utensils, bags and shoes out of her home. She stocks up in Lomé in Togo, the country which is a neighbor of Benin. In order to strengthen her business and better respond to customer demand, Vidéhoun is seeking a loan from ALIDé, with the goal of increasing her revenues.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing kitchen utensils [for resale]

loans.name: Jamson

texts.en:
On Bufunda Street, Ibanda town, exists a hardworking and determined B. Jamson who has been running a produce business for a period of thirty years where he sell foodstuffs and animals. As a matter of fact, determination and hard work have brought him this far along in his businesses selling bananas and goats.

This loan will help Jamson to do more research on better quality of products he trades in like rice, maize, beans and sorghum and to further restock his business in order to match his customers’ demand. With an improved business he will be able to earn more revenue and be able to develop his family in the future as he struggles to educate his eleven children to make them better people.

loans.use: To restock and expand his business by buying more goats and bananas to sell

loans.name: Sope Serigne Barra Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SERIGNE BARRA est créé en 2007, il a 3 ans d'existence, il est composé de 08 femmes issues du même village. Elles sont âgées entre 30 et 60 ans, mariées et mères d'au moins 3  enfants. Les membres du groupe ont longtemps travailler ensemble,depuis plus de 05 ans et elles sont pratiquement de la même concession. Elles ont eu à développer beaucoup d'activités à savoir les tontines (crédit de petits montants rotatifs) des rencontres d'information et de sensibilisation, etc. L'activité dominante du groupe est le commerce de céréales locales et l'embouche bovine et ovine. Leur nouveau prêt les aidera à mieux développer ces activités en augmentant les quantités d'approvisionnement en marchandises et à améliorer les conditions de l'embouche.

Madame Amy G., debout à l'extrême droit de la photo est la responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants en charge. Elle est détentrice d'une boutique au marché de Diourbel, sa capitale régionale. Son prêt est destiné à augmenter la quantité de marchandises de sa boutique composées de riz, d'huile végétale, de sucre, des différentes boîtes de concertes etc. l'objectif de son crédit est de réaliser des bénéfices qui lui permettront de couvrir les besoins scolaires et sanitaires de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The solidarity group SERIGNE BARRA was created in 2007 and has been in existence for three years.  It is composed of eight women from the same village.  The women range in age from 30 to 60, and they are married mothers of at least 3 children.  The group members have worked together for a long time, for over five years.  They have practically the same concession.  They have had to develop many activities, namely tontines (small rotating loans), information meetings, awareness meetings, etc.  The main business of the group involves commerce in local grains and the fattening of cattle and sheep. Their new loan will help them to develop these businesses further by increase the quantity of supplies of merchandise and by improving the conditions for their livestock. Ms. Amy G. (standing at the far right in the photo) is the head of the solidarity group.  She is 48 years old, married, and the mother of six children to support.  She has a shop at the market of Diourbel, the regional capital.  Her loan is for increasing the quantity of merchandise in her shop:  rice, vegetable oil, sugar, different canned foods, etc.  The goal of her loan is to make a profit, which will enable her to meet the schooling and health care needs of her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing the businesses of the solidarity group

loans.name: Anne Sènoumè

texts.fr: A. Anne Sènoumè est née le 26 Juillet 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à SETIN Noël, Anne Sènoumè est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Anne Sènoumè vit avec sa famille à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis quinze ans environs. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différentes charges familiales. Anne Sènoumè a très peu fréquenté l'école. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Anne Sènoumè prépare et vend de l'akassa (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Anne Sènoumè vend du pétrole à son domicile. Anne Sènoumè fait ses provisions à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans l'optique de renforcer son capital et d'augmenter le volume de sa production alimentaire, pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Anne Sènoumè sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un autre prêt.
texts.en:
Ms. A. Anne Sènoumè was born on July 26, 1970 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to Mr. SETIN Noël, she is the mother of four children who are all in school.  She has lived with her family in Djeffa, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, for about fifteen years.  The couple jointly cover their family's difference expenses.  Anne has had very little schooling.  For about ten years, she has been making and selling akassa (a local food made with corn starch) at her home.  Secondarily, she sell kerosene out of her home.  She gets her provisions at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous client of ALIDé having already had five loans, which were all repaid.  With regard to bolstering her food production and satisfying her customers further, Anne is requesting another loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn and some kerosene

texts.en: Annette is divorced with six children, and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. Annette works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. Formerly, she was dealing in local gin but changed her business enterprise to a retail shop. She has been operating this retail shop for three months. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, boxes of soap, and cartons of salt.  In addition to this retail shop business, she also sells cosmetics. She sells to all categories of people. Her customers are people from the village who work seven days a week. Her business challenges include transportation and seasonality. Annette aspires to own her house and expand her business. She joined MCDT because of timely loans at the village level. She resides in and rents a two-room house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees, rent and food.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
El señor Edgar tiene 31 años de edad, viven en pareja con la señora María, tienen 2 hijos en edad escolar, su domicilio está situado en una compañía muy concurrida de la ciudad de Itá denominada Las Piedras.
Se dedican a la confección de trajes para particulares y para agentes policiales de la ciudad Asunción y  alrededores sobre pedido, realiza dicha actividad hace más de 10 años, su taller de confecciones lo tiene instalado en su domicilio.
 El préstamo que solicita en esta ocasión es para la compra de una maquina recta, la cual le servirá para agilizar la confección de sus trajes.
 La microempresa del señor Edgar origina fuente de trabajo a 1 empleado fijo, y a otras personas que realizan la terminación de las prendas.
El señor Edgar cuenta con la ayuda económica de su cónyuge quien es comerciante, posee una despensa en su domicilio.
texts.en:
Edgar is 31 years old and lives together with his wife María. They have two school-aged children. His home is located in a very busy neighborhood in the city of Itá called Las Piedras. He works making suits for individuals and for police officers of the city of Asunción and surrounding areas upon request. He has been doing this activity for 10 years. He has his sewing shop set up in his home. The loan that he requests is for the purchase of a sewing machine, which will speed up the process of making tailored clothing. Edgar’s small business created a source of work for one permanent employee and for other people who have helped with the production of garments. Edgar depends on financial support from his spouse, a merchant who runs a store in their home.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha Cerone, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Joël

texts.fr:
M. Joël 45 ans marie avec 6 enfants, née en district de Bugesera, province de l’est du Rwanda, mais il vit avec sa famille à Kigali. 
Il est Evangéliste de l’Eglise de Pentecôte du Rwanda, à part ça il est commerçant détaillant en boutique, il a commencé cette activité en 1990 avec un capital de 1500 Rrw, pendant le génocide perpétré contre les  tutsi de 1994, il a tout perdu, il s’est reconstruit après cette guerre en  commercialisant les marchandises des autres jusqu'à ce qu’il en tire le capital pour commencer sa boutique.Les épargnes continuelles lui a aidé de construire sa propre maison.Les bénéfices tirés dans la boutique combiné du salaire de l’Eglise font qu’il peut faire vivre sa famille. Avec Amasezerano il a remboursé un prêt. Il a contracté un autre pour acheter les haricots, sucre, savons pour augmenter la capacité de sa boutique.ses ambitions et que dans l’avenir est ’acheter une moto pour lui facilité de transport journalière, construire d’autres maisons à louer.
texts.en:
M. Joël, aged 45, is married and has six children.  He was born in the district of Bugesera, Eastern Province, Rwanda.  But he lives with his family in Kigali.  He is the assistant pastor of the Pentacost Church of Rwanda.  Aside from this, he is a retail shopkeeper.  Joël started this business in 1990 with 1,500 RWF in capital.  During the genocide perpetrated against the Tutsi in 1994, he lost everything.  He rebuilt after the war by selling the merchandise of others until he derived the capital for starting his own shop. Saving continuously helped him to build his own house.  The profits from his shop combined with his church salary means he can provide for his family.  With Amasezerano, Joël has repaid a loan.  He has signed another loan for buying beans, sugar, and soaps for increasing the capacity of his shop.  His ambitions for the future involve buying a motorbike to facilitate his transport each day and to build other houses to rent.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sugar, beans, salt, and soaps for his shop

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
El Sr. Luis tiene 39 años, está casado con la Sra. Sonia hace 17 años, tienen 3 hijos, todos ellos varones: Walter (21), Juan Luis (14) y Jorge Ramón (13) ,los tres chicos se encuentran estudiando.
El Sr. Luis anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de leche y poseía una carnicería, comenta que comenzó a interesarse por la Veterinaria y comenzó a estudiar hasta que se recibió de Doctor en Veterinaria, desde entonces, exactamente hace 2 años que posee su Agro-Veterinaria donde trabaja en compañía de su esposa.
 En dicho lugar atiende a una buena cantidad de clientes, quienes se encuentran muy contentos con el servicio.
El Sr. Luis solicita el  préstamo para la instalación de una peluquería para mascotas.
texts.en:
Luis, 39, has been married to Sonia for seventeen years. They have three children, all of them boys: Walter, 21, Juan Luis, 14, and Jorge Ramón, 13. The three boys are all students. Luis used to sell milk and had a butcher shop. He says that he became interested in Veterinary Science and studied until he received his degree. Since then he has run Agro-Veterinaria for exactly two years, where he works with his wife. His business serves a lot of customers who are very happy with his service. Luis requests a loan for the installation of a pet grooming salon.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha Cerone, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of a pet grooming salon

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is married with three children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall in Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, selling second-hand clothes. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for seven years. She does not incur transportation costs, as she buys from the place where she works. She works six days a week. Harriet sells her products retail to a variety of people. She joined MCDT in order to generate capital and because of the low interest rates. She is aspiring to sell wholesale only. Harriet resides in and rents a two-room house. The family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses includes rent, school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To buy bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Jmv

texts.en:
Jmv is 35 years old and married. He has 2 children. His first child is 5 years old and the last one is 3 years old. Jmv takes care of four dependents in his family. Jmv's wife is a teacher. They both work to develop their family so that they can progress in their daily activities. 

Jmv sells various products, as you can see in the photo. He has 15 years of experience in his business. His business is open from 5:00 a.m. in the morning to 9:00 p.m. in the evening every day.

Now, Jmv is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing more products, which can attract more customers. Once these customers are reached, Jmv will be able to earn more profit.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more dry meat to improve business.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr:
CES amies l'appelle maman jacky, célibataire, mère de 4 enfants dont l'âge varient entre 32ans et 24ans dont 1 seul, le plus pétit va encore à l'école, une de ses filles est mariée.
Elle a commencée avec la vente du manioc en 1978 avec un capital de 30000francs, le travail du manioc trés dur, elle s'est lancée dans la vente des fruits.
Le commerce des fruits est une bonne affaire, car à  chaque saison dans son pays, correspond une production des fruits,pendant la saison des pluits, il ya des magues, avocats, barbadines et beaucoup d' autres fruits sauvages et pendant la saison sèche, il ya les oranges, les mandarines, les pomplemousses, bananes.
Pour le Prêt actuel , elle voudrai maintenant achéter sa marchandise au comptant(paiement cash),et achéter les fruits exotiques qui coutent très chèrs par exemple les littys, les mangoustons, les pommes.
Ces recettes journalieres sont de 35000f pendant les temps favorables et 15000f l'activité est en baisse.
Pour son avénir, elle veut lancer une de ses filles dans ce commerce qu'elle trouve avantageux et souténir celui qui va à l'école de poursuivre ses études dans les meilleurs conditions.
Elle a une vision D'économiser pour être riche afin d'acheter un terrain pour planter les arbres fruitiers.
texts.en:
Her friends call her “Mommy Jacky”. She is a single mother of four children whose ages range from 24 to 32 and only one of which, the youngest, is still in school. One of her daughters is married. She started selling cassava in 1978 with a capital of 30,000 francs. Because working with cassava is so hard, she started selling fruit. The sale of fruit is good business because in her country, each season produces fruit. During the rainy season there are mangos, avocados, granadillas and many other wild fruits. During the dry season there are oranges, mandarins, grapefruits and bananas. She would like to use the current loan for a cash purchase of stocks and to buy exotic fruits, which are very expensive (e.g. litchis, mangosteens and apples.) Her daily revenues reach 35,000F during high-activity periods and decrease to 15,000F when sales slow down. In the future, she plans to get one of her daughters started in this profitable business and to help her youngest child pursue his studies in the best conditions. Her vision is to save money and become wealthy enough to buy land where she would plant fruit trees.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen her business by purchasing fruit such as oranges, African plums, pineapples, papayas, lemons, mangos.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is widowed with six children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a store selling charcoal in Kyebando Nsooba. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She has been in the charcoal business for six years. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans and doesn’t incur any transport costs because she buys from her place of work. She sells to all types of people, at both retail and wholesale, and her customers are from the community around her home. In addition to this charcoal business, she also owns a bar. Margaret's business challenges includes price fluctuations and the rainy season. She aspires to educate her children up to university. She joined MCDT because they are giving loans without collateral. Margaret resides in and rents a two-room house, and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food, and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.en:

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Jimmy has been engaged in his business for more than five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jimmy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jimmy is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jimmy from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
Oscar tiene 22 años, es soltero, vive con sus padres.
 Él se dedica a la venta y reparación de celulares hace 2 años.
 Anteriormente trabajaba para otra persona pero con la práctica y el estudio que tiene decidió independizarse y montar su propio negocio. 
 Hoy día ya cuenta con clientela propia muy bien formada y su negocio va creciendo día a día.
El crédito que solicita en esta oportunidad es para la compra de mercaderías para su negocio tales como: celulares, accesorios, carcasas, etc.
texts.en:
Oscar is 22 years old, single, and lives with his parents. He has been selling and repairing cell phones for 2 years. Previously, he worked for another person but with the practice and study that he has, he decided to become independent and start up his own business. Now he has his own well-established clientele and his business is growing day by day.

The loan that he is requesting at this time is for the purchase of merchandise for his business, such as: cell phones, accessories, casing, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cell phones, casing, cell phone accessories, etc.
