loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
At 41 years old, Jacqueline is a proven entrepreneur. She is well known in the business of selling new clothes to both men and women. Jacqueline has been in this business for about 3 years and her business is open from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. every day.

Jacqueline is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. Hopefully, this loan will allow her to keep retailing and start wholesaling to her customers.  With this loan, Jacqueline will purchase more items to sell. She hopes to earn more profits, and these profits will help her to operate the same business in other areas.

loans.use: Different styles of new clothes for sale

loans.name: Ramon

texts.es:
El señor Ramón vive en concubinato con la señora Efigenia Aquino hace más de 10 años, tienen 3 hijos en edad escolar, viven en un barrio cercano al centro de la ciudad de Itá.
El mismo posee una despensa en su domicilio donde surte a sus vecinos y a ocasionales clientes de todo tipo de insumos y artículos de primera necesidad para el hogar como ser bebidas en general, arroz, azúcar, yerba, lácteos y otras mercaderías.
 Opera con la Fundación Paraguaya hace mas de 1 año en forma excelente, además de la despensa el señor Ramón posee un taller mecánico donde realiza servicios de reparación y mantenimiento de todo tipo de motocicletas, lo cual también le genera buenos ingresos. El préstamo que solicita es para aumentar su stock de mercaderías comprando mercaderías tales como: bebidas en gral., lácteos, yerba, arroz, etc.
texts.en:
Ramón has lived with Efigenia Aquino for the past 10 years. They have 3 school-aged children and live in a neighborhood close to the center of the city of Itá.

He has a store in his house where he supplies his neighbors and occasional customers with all types of groceries and basic need items for the home such as drinks, rice, sugar, yerba, dairy products and other products.

He has worked excellently with Fundación Paraguaya for more than a year. In addition to the store, Ramón also has a mechanic shop where he has repair services and maintenance of all types of motorcycles, which also generates good earnings. The loan that he is requesting is to increase his stock of merchandise by purchasing items such as: drinks, dairy products, yerba, rice, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of drinks, dairy products, yerba, rice, and other products.

loans.name: Ayudanos Señor 6 Group

texts.en:
Johanny is the coordinator of her group Ayudanos Señore (Help Us Lord), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, an area where the economy is dominated by the sugarcane harvest and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children.

Johanny is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a small food stand by purchasing bananas, rice, charcoal and cola to sell.

She also plans to purchase a sewing machine to start a second business doing clothing alterations. She will use the profits to save and reinvest in her business. Her long term goal is to own and operate her own supermarket.

loans.use: To purchase rice, bananas, charcoal, cola to sell, and a sewing machine to start a new business.

loans.name: Santa Lucía Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inició con la Señora Donatilda A.  integrante del comité “Santa Lucia” de la zona del  km 10 Acaray, la misma contactó   con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en dicha zona. 
El comité se encuentra dentro del  Décimo Tercer  ciclo y todas se encuentran muy entusiasmada de seguir trabajando con el grupo.
La señora Catalina G. quien se dedica a la obstetricia es una de las integrantes del comité.
Ella adquirió esta profesión con muchos cursos que realizo siendo joven y actualmente con esta actividad mantiene a su familia.
Ella solicita el préstamo para  realizar algunas mejoras a su consultorios entre pinturas, cambio de pisos y otros, agradece por la ayuda.
texts.en:
The formation of this current group began with Donatilda A., member of the “Santa Lucía” group in the kilometer 10 Acaray zone. She contacted her neighbors and friends to form the group in this zone.

The group is in its thirteenth loan cycle and all of them are very enthusiastic to continue working with the group.

Catalina G., who works in obstetrics, is one of the members of the group. She entered this profession with many courses that she completed when she was young and she currently maintains her family with this job.

She is requesting the loan to make some improvements to her office like paintings, changing the flooring and others. She is grateful for the help.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flooring and paintings, in addition to payment for the labor.

loans.name: Cotamoru Group

texts.fr:
M. Kizito, jeune gens de 23 ans, célibataire, il n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il vit avec sa mère et trois frères et une sœur. C’est lui qui est responsable de la famille.
Membre du groupe appelé COTAMORU (Coopérative de taxi motards de Rubavu),  qui est un groupe de transporteurs de taxi moto, c’est un groupe d’une cinquantaine des membres subdivisé en petits groupes de dix personnes. Beaucoup d’entre eux utilisent les motos qui ne sont pas les leurs. Kizito, lui a besoin un prêt pour augmenter ses épargnes pour acheter sa propre moto. Comme tout autre groupe, il donne une garantie de caution solidaire.
Kizito et son groupe travail pour augmenter la capacité financière de leur groupe, et valoriser leur business. En fait, le groupe a contracté n prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles pour ravitailler leur business.les bénéfices récoltés de leur business sont réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer leur meilleur future.

Concernant le groupe
Un prêt de groupe signifie que chaque membre prend son montant et l’utiliser pour son propre business, l’avantage est que le groupe garantisse pour les prêts individuels de chaque membre et si un membre devient garant de ses engagements, tout les membres du groupe remboursent à sa place.
texts.en:
M. Kizito, aged 23, is an unmarried young man who did not attend school.  He lives with his mother, three brothers, and a sister.  Kizito is the head of the family.  He is a member of the group called COTAMORU (Coopérative de taxi motards de Rubavu), a co-op of motobike taxi drivers of Rubavu which is a group of about fifty members subdivided into small groups of ten persons.  Many of them use motorbikes that are not theirs.  Kizito himself has need of a loan to increase his savings in order to purchase his own motorbike.  As with any other group, he is jointly guaranteed.    Kizito and his group work to increase the financial capacity of their group and to upgrade their businesses.  In fact, the group has signed a loan with Amasezerano Community Banking to buy goods to supply their businesses.  The profits gathered from their business are reinvested to maintain the group's financial stability and to save money in order to have a better future.  Concerning the group. A group loan means that each member takes his amount and uses it for his own business.  The advantage is that the group guarantees the individual loans.  And if a member becomes answerable for his commitments, all the members of the group pay up for him.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a motorbike for transport

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: Née en 1961, F. Bernadette vit depuis seize ans au quartier Zounga à Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Bernadette est mariée à AVOKPAHO Antoine et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Bernadette et Antoine ont deux autres enfants à leurs charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Bernadette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec son mari les différentes charges familiales. Bernadette n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Bernadette mène comme activité, la vente de sacs de charbon de bois et de maïs à son domicile. C'est dans le nord du Bénin que Bernadette achète ses produits. Bernadette exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année et a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Bernadette désire accroître davantage son activité et gagner une grande part de marché à Cocotomey et environs, ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenus. C'est pourquoi Bernadette sollicite un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1961, Bernadette F. has been living in the Zounga district of Cocotomey in the Abomey Calavi commune for the past sixteen years. She is married to Antoine Avokpaho and has two children, both in school. Bernadette and Antoine also care for two other children in addition to their own. Bernadette helps her husband to make sure the family is well taken care of. Bernadette has never been to school. Bernadette sells bags of charcoal and maize from her home in order to make enough money to take care of her needs. She buys her stock in the north of Benin. She has been doing this for about ten years and has already paid back two loans. Bernadette wants to expand her business and gain a bigger share of the market in Cocotomey and the surrounding areas, which will help her generate more income. This is why Bernadette is asking for a third loan.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 50 bags of charcoal and 50 bags of maize.

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.es:
Santa Librada se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Yaguarón en fecha 20 de febrero de 2009.
La Sra. Adelia P. es una de las integrantes y posee una Despensa, la cual es bastante concurrida por los pobladores de la zona, siendo que está bien surtida y por la amabilidad que caracteriza a la señora.
Ella desea ampliar el negocio, con la compra de artículos de primera necesidad, enlatados, empaquetados, artículos de limpieza, mercería, bazár, ferretería, librería; todo esto en mayor cantidad, de modo a mantener los precios bajos y ser buena competencia en el mercado y al mismo tiempo incrementar sus ingresos por este fin solicita el prestamo.
texts.en:
This excellent group of women is called Santa Librada. The group was formed in the city of Yagauarón on February 20th, 2009. Adelia Periera is one of the members. She has a grocery store, which is much frequented by the area’s inhabitants. This is because it is well stocked and because of her characteristic friendliness. She wishes to expand her business by purchasing basic needs items like canned goods, packaged goods, cleaning supplies, notions, bazaar items, hardware, and bookstore products. She will buy all of this in greater quantity. That way she will keep the prices low and be good competition in the market. At the same time her income will increase. That is why she is requesting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a greater quantity of basic needs articles like canned goods, packaged goods, cleaning supplies, notions, bazaar items, hardware, and bookstore products

loans.name: Rwambona Group

texts.en:
Epiphanie was born in 1961. She is married and has five children between the ages of 10 and 26. Most of Epiphanie’s children are mature. She also cares for one dependent from her family, even though she has to take care of many people   

Epiphanie is leader of the Rwambona loan group. This group has six members, five men and only one woman. 

Epiphanie sells sorghum and beans. This is a profitable business where she lives. Her business is open from 5:00 a.m. in the morning to 10:00 p.m. in the evening every day except Saturday.

Epiphanie is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing more sorghum and beans. With this loan, Epiphanie will be able to satisfy her customers.

loans.use: A large quantity of beans, sorghum, etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase and diversify her clothing merchandise for winter

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre, Mujeres Emprendedoras se conformó en fecha 17 de mayo del 2006, mediante las promociones que realizó la Asesora en la zona, y gracias a la actual Directora General se comformó el Comité, que se encuentra integrado por 19 mujeres y  siguen trabajando  con el mismo entusiamo y esfuerzo,  ya se encuentra el 14º ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
La Señora Marciana Oporto es una de las integrantes y trabaja en su casa como ama de casa y tambien posee una Despensa bastante surtida, por lo que tiene una buena clientela ya formada.
Tiene intenciones de incrementar sus ingresos mediante la ampliación de su despensa, a la cual desea agregar más productos de artículos de ferretería y electricidad para el hogar, como focos, portalamparas, etc. que son muy solicitados por los por los pobladores, ella desea adquirir en gran cantidad  ya que el costo se abarataria bastante y por ende aumentando sus ingresos para concretar este objetivo ella solicta el prestamo.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Emprendedoras (Enterprising Women) Communal Bank was formed on May 17th of 2006, because of the publicity done by the advisor in the area. Thanks to the current general director, they formed the group, which is comprised of 19 women. The women continue working with the same enthusiasm and effort. They are in their fourteenth cycle, and they work in a cohesive and supportive way within the program. Marciana Oportoa is one of the members. She works in her house as a housewife, and she also has a well stocked grocery store. She has a good customer base. She plans to increase her income by expanding her grocery store. She wishes to add more hardware and electrical products for the home. She will add things like light bulbs and lamp holders, etc. People request these items a lot. She wants to get a large quantity because the price will be a great deal lower. She wants to do this to increase her income. She is requesting the loan in order to meet this objective.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy hardware and electrical products for the home like light bulbs and lamp holders, etc.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Née le 17 Septembre 1982 à Sikasso, Fatoumata B. est divorcée et mère de deux garçons. Elle vit dans  une grande traditionnelle élargie à Médine-Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, Fatoumata B. s’est initiée  à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’articles  d’alimentation il y a maintenant cinq ans. Elle mène son activité devant son domicile à Médine Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une année. Elle a bénéficié d’un premier prêt qui a été très bien remboursé.
Ce deuxième prêt lui permettra d’acheter auprès de ses fournisseurs de Sikasso mais aussi de Bamako,  38 casiers de boissons BRAMALI, 50 paquets de boissons NBB, 60 cartons d’eau minérale, 30 cartons de boissons en canette (Malta, Vimto, Ivorio, etc), 5 cartons de lait Candia, 15 paquets d’eau minérale en sachets, 5 cartons de biscuits de qualité différentes, etc.
Les marchandises sont vendues en gros et en détail au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes, d’hommes et de jeunes. 
Avec ce deuxième prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 270 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on September 17, 1982 in Sikasso, Ms. Fatoumata B. is a divorced mother of two boys.  She lives in a large traditional extended family in Médine-Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After having work in many business unsuccessfully, she got introduced five years ago to the business of buying and selling foodstuffs.  She operates in front her home in Médine Sikasso, where she is much in demand by her customers for the quality of her products.  To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Fatoumata decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about a year ago.  She has had an initial loan, which has been repaid.  This second loan will enable her to buy the following goods from  suppliers in Sikasso but also in Bamako:  38 cases of BRAMALI drinks, 50 packets of NBB drinks, 60 boxes of mineral water, 30 boxes of canned drinks (Malta, Vimto, Ivorio, etc.), 5 boxes of Candia milk, 15 packets of mineral water in pouches, 5 boxes of different cookies, etc.  The goods are sold wholesale and retail, for cash or on credit, to a customer base composed of women, men, and youngsters.   With this second loan, Fatoumata envisions making monthly profit of 270,000 that will be used essentially for increase her working capital, helping to cover family expenses, and paying the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise as supplies

loans.name: Ruby Elizabeth

texts.es: Ruby tiene 23 años  de edad es soltera vive  con sus padres ella tiene un pequeño negocio del servcio de fotocopias, se inicio con el apoyo de sus padres. Ella tambien trabaja por las mañanas prestando servcio domesticos  como ama de casa. Clienta joven con muchos deseos de superacion metas y objetivos uno de ellos es poder crecer en su negocio. Con el dinero que solicita invertira en capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Ruby, 23 years old, is single and lives with her parents. She has a small photocopy service business which she started with the help of her parents. She also works mornings providing domestic house keeper service. This young client has a great desire to meet her goals and objectives, one of which is to be able to expand her business. With the loan she is requesting she will invest in working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For working capital

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: Y. Philomène est née le 30 Juin 1972 et est mariée à METONOU Ludovic. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a près de quinze ans que Philomène s'est installée au quartier Wlacodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins du foyer. Il y a environs douze ans que Philomène mène comme activité la vente de produits de mer (poissons et crevettes) à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Philomène vend également de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs accompagnée de sauce aux poissons et aux crevettes). Philomène achète ses produits de mer au Port de pêche à Cotonou. Philomène est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a toujours bien remboursé ses crédits. En vue d'élever davantage le niveau de son activité et d'accroître encore plus sa clientèle, Philomène sollicite un autre crédit pour augmenter ses stocks de produits.
texts.en:
Philomène Y. was born June 30, 1972 and is married to Ludovic Metonou. The couple has two children who are both in school. Nearly fifteen years ago, Philomène moved to the neighborhood of Wlacodji in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, where she lives with her children and her husband. Together, the couple supports their various household needs. For almost twelve years, Philomène has been in business selling seafood (fish and shrimp) in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Philomène also sells food (rice, corn pastries in a sauce of fish and shrimp). Philomène buys her seafood at the fish port in Cotonou. Philomène is a long-time customer of ALIDé, who has always successfully paid back her loans. With an eye to raising her level of business and growing her customer base even more, Philomène is requesting an additional loan to increase her stocks of her products.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, corn, sauces, and seafood (fish and shrimp)

loans.name: Bendiciones De Dios 1,2,3 Group

texts.en:
Islen is the coordinator of her group Bendiciones D. Dios (Blessings of God), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest dominates the economy and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her common-law husband and their two children.

Islen is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza  after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing by purchasing sandals, pants and blouses to sell. She will use the profits to invest in constructing her home.

loans.use: to buy blouses, pants and sandals

loans.name: Issa

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Issa D.  a plus de 38 ans, polygame et père de six  enfants dont 4 garçons et 2 filles. Il réside avec ses quatre femmes et leurs enfants dans sa propre maison à Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès notamment l’agriculture et autres, il s’est vite initié aux activités de stockage et commercialisation de  produits agricoles tels le pois sucré et les noix de karité il y’a 10 ans. 
Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes de l’extérieur, mais les ressources financières nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins font défaut. 
Ainsi, il  décida d’intégrer Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il a bénéficié de deux prêts  individuels qui ont été  tous correctement remboursés. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il sollicite ce troisième prêt pour d’acheter, 30 sacs de pois sucré, 1 tonne de maïs, 5 sacs de mil et 10 sacs de noix de karité. 
Il s’approvisionne dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso  pour d’abord les stocker dans son magasin situé au nouveau de Médine Sikasso. Ensuite il les ramène à Abidjan et à Bobo Dioulasso (respectivement dans les républiques de Côte d’Ivoire et Burkina Faso) sur commande des usines de fabrique de jus de pois sucré et de beurre de karité. Il vend les céréales à la fois en gros et en détail.    
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 315 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Issa D. is over 38 years old, and is the polygamous father of six children, of whom four are boys and two are girls. He lives with his four wives and their children in his own house in Médine, one of the working-class boroughs of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After practicing several unsuccessful activities –farming being one of them- he soon began ten years ago stockpiling activities and commercialisation of agricultural products such as sugar peas and shea nuts. Given his amount of experience, he enjoys a strong reputation and even receives a number of orders from outside the country. Unfortunately, he lacks the financial means to satisfy these requests. He therefore decided to join Soro Yiriwaso where he has already been granted two loans, both repaid in full. Wanting to satisfy an ever-increasing customer base, he is requesting a third loan to buy 30 bags of sugar peas, one ton of corn, 5 bags of millet, and 10 bags of shea nuts. He gets his supplies from villages in the vicinity of Sikasso and stockpiles them to start with at his store in the new area of Médine in Sikasso. He then transports the products to Abidjan (Côte d’Ivoire) and Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso), in response to orders from factories producing sugar pea juice and shea butter. He sells grain crereals both wholesale and retail. He hopes this loan will enable him to reach monthly earnings of 315,000 FCFA, which will be used to cover most of his own expenses, those of his family and to pay the loan interest. The remainder will be reinvested in his business activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Kuña Kyrey Group

texts.es:
El Comité D. Mujeres D. nombre Kuña Kyrey, se conformó en fecha 14 D. Julio del 2008, gracias a que la Directora General, la Sra.Cynthia D. tomo la iniciativa D. invitar a sus amigas y D. esa forma lograron formar el comite .
La Señora Cynthia D. D. Orué es una mujer muy emprendedora y va sobresaliendo gracias al negocio D. Mercería que posee, es bastante concurrido siendo que tiene gran variedad D. mercaderías y a precios bastante accesibles, para regalos o D. uso personal y en el hogar.
La Señora desea incrementar sus ingresos sin elevar los costos D. sus mercaderías, por lo que pretenD. ampliar el negocio con la compra al por mayor D. telas, apliques para ropas, apliques para el hogar, arreglos decorativos, etc., abaratando así los costos y al mismo tiempo aumentar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
The Kuña Kyrey Communal Bank was formed on July 14th, 2008, thanks to the general director. Cynthia D. took the initiative to invite her friends, and they formed the group. Cynthia D. D. Orué is a very enterprising woman. She is excelling thanks to the notions store that she has. It is pretty busy because it has a great variety of merchandise, and the prices are very accessible. Her items can be gifts, for personal use, and for the home. She wishes to increase her income without raising the cost of her merchandise. She intends to expand her business by purchasing wholesale fabrics, appliques for clothes, appliques for the home, and decorative arrangements, etc. Buying this way makes the costs cheaper and, at the same time, her income increases.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabrics, appliques for clothes, appliques for the home, and decorative arrangements, etc.

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia B. a 30 ans, mariée et mère de deux filles. Elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I-Kapel Kourou, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadidia B. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’huile alimentaire, de couscous arabe,  de cube maggi etc il y a maintenant six ans. Elle mène son activité à la maison et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose  d’une place. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans. Elle est actuellement à son 3ème prêt individuel et les deux précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 8 bidons d’huile alimentaire, 3 cartons de couscous arabe, 5 cartons de  cube maggi, 3 cartons du thé Arawane, etc. 
Elle  achète ses marchandises sur commande à Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso) et aussi dans les huileries de  la place avant de les revendre en détail au marché de leur localité.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadidia B. is 30 years old, married and the mother of two girls. She lives with her husband and their children in Sanoubougou I-Kapel Kourou, one of the boroughs on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having tried several activities without success, Mrs. Kadidia B. began six years ago the commerce of vegetable oil, Arabian couscous, and “Maggi” cubes. She runs her business at home and at her neighbourhood market where she has a reserved emplacement. She is very much in demand by her customers due to the quality of her products. To satisfy their increasing numbers, she decided two years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. She is now requesting a third loan, having repaid both preceding ones. She will use this loan to buy 8 containers of vegetable oil, 3 packages of Arabian couscous, 5 packages of Maggi cubes, 3 packages of Arawane tea, etc. She orders her products from Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) and from local oil producers, before retailing them in their local market. She hopes this loan will help her attain monthly earnings of 100,000 FCFA, which will be used essentially to increase her working capital, contribute towards family expenses and pay her loan interests.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Dona Georges

texts.fr: D. Dona Georges  est né en 1975 à Aguégué, dans le département de l’Ouémé. Marié à KPATINVOH Félicienne, une coiffeuse, Georges  est père de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Georges  vit avec sa famille à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis près de huit ans. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Georges  a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Georges   vend divers produits (conserves de sardine, de tomate, lait, huile d’arachide, huile de palme, œufs, sachets, savons, pâtes alimentaires, etc.) dans sa boutique size à son domicile. Georges  exerce cette activité depuis environs cinq ans. C’est un ancien client de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois prêts qu’il a eu à tous bien rembourser. Georges  désire renforcer son activité et augmenter ses ventes, ce qui lui permettra d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
Dona Georges D. was born in 1975 in Aguégué, in the district of Ouémé. He is married to Félicienne Kpatinvoh, a hairdresser. Georges has three children, all of whom attend school. He has lived with his family in Ekpè, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji, for eight years. The couple shares the family’s responsibilities and expenses. George stopped attending school before high school. To support his family, he sells a variety of products, such as canned sardines, tomatoes, milk, peanut and palm oil, eggs, pasta, soap and plastic bags. His boutique is located in his home. He has had this business for five years. A seasoned client of ALIDé, he has already received and repaid three previous loans. He has requested this fourth loan to strengthen his business and improve sales which will increase his income.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods for resale, such as canned sardines and tomatoes, pasta, soap and plastic bags

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 26 Décembre 1963 à N’Kourala préfecture de Sikasso, Mariam Koné est veuve et mère de quatre enfants. Elle réside avec ses enfants  à Médine-Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mariam Koné, après avoir perdu son époux il y a dix sept ans, s’est initiée au commerce d’achat et de vente de produits  alimentaires. Elle vend au nouveau marché dont elle dispose d’un magasin et d’une table où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Ainsi elle a bénéficié d’un premier  prêt  qui a été même remboursé par anticipation. 
Dans le but de toujours mieux relancer son activité, elle sollicite un deuxième prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter, 15 sacs d’oignons de graines différentes, 5 sacs de pomme de terre  et un important  stock de condiments alimentaires.
 Elle achète ses marchandises sur place avec les paysans venus des villages environnants et dans les marchés hebdomadaires de Yorosso et Kouri vers la frontière Mali-Burkina Faso pour être vendues en détail ou en gros au comptant les jours de foire à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 175 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on December 26, 1963 in N’Kourala, Sikasso Prefecture, Mariam Koné is a widow and the mother of four children. She lives with her children in Médine-Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Following the loss of her husband seventeen years ago, Mariam Koné got started in business by buying and selling food products. She sells at the new market where she has a shop and a display. She is very much sought after by customers for the quality of her products. In order to meet the needs of her ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organization. She has already received a first loan that she even paid off in advance. In order to keep on boosting her activity, she is requesting a second loan that will enable her to purchase 15 sacks of onions of different types, 5 sacks of potatoes and a large stock of food condiments. She buys her supplies locally from farmers coming from nearby villages and in the Yorosso and Kouri weekly markets close to the Mali-Burkina Faso border. She sells these products for cash, retail or wholesale, during fair days to a customer base comprising mainly fair vendors. With this loan, she hopes to make a monthly profit of 175,000 CFA francs that will be mostly used to increase her working capital, help with family expenses and pay the interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Josee

texts.en:
Josee was born in 1963 and is married. Josee is a farmer and a woman who is serious, because she has a big place where she can work. Josee has 10 years of experience in agriculture and livestock. She employs two people full time for her business.

Josee is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to buy more cows so she can expand her business by employing more people. Once she is able to do this, Josee will be able to earn more profit from her daily activities.

loans.use: Expanding her business of agriculture and livestock

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Âgée de 30 ans, Madame Mariam Traoré N. est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame à Médine-Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée il y a deux ans environs à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’oignons au nouveau marché dont elle dispose d’une table où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son  premier prêt individuel, qui sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter, 15 sacs d’oignons de graines différentes (9 sacs de petites graines et 6 sacs de grosses graines) auprès des producteurs. Ses marchandises sont vendues au comptant à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes de ménages.
Avec ce premier crédit elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariam Traoré N. is 30 years old, married and the mother of two children. She lives in a monogamous famly in Médine-Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run several businesses without success, around two years ago she started the business of buying and selling onions at the new market where she has a table. She is much sought after by her customers for the quality of her products. In order to satisfy her growing clientele, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution; this is her first request for an individual loan. This loan will be used to increase her working capital in order to purchase 15 bags of different varieties of onions (9 bags of small varieties and 6 bags of large varieties) from producers. She sells her merchandise for cash to a customer base composed essentially of housewives. With this first loan she anticipates realizing an average monthly profit of 90,000 CFA that will be used principally to increase her working capital, contribute to the family’s expenses and to pay the interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase onions

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.es: Wilfredo es un emprendedor hombre de 23 años, comparte su vida con su esposa Mireya de 24 años. Ambos viven juntos en casa de sus suegros. Hace mas de 5 años, se dedica en la fabricación de puertas, ventanas, entre otros objetos de metal, en el taller que le pertenece a su suegra. Cuando se unió con su esposa, ambos decidieron trabajar muy duro para sacar adelante el negocio familiar. Wilfredo al ver a  su suegro todas las ganas y el empeño que le pone a su trabajo, él también desea trabajar con ese mismo empuje, siendo el único fin, de mejorar este taller de fabricación. Por otro lado su suegra se encarga de la administración, es así que Wilfredo y su familia distribuyen el trabajo. En un futuro, desea instalar su propio negocio, solo espera que el taller de su suegro este bien constituido y no necesiten de su ayuda. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP y siempre se caracterizó por ser muy responsable con sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará materiales para completar el trabajo de fabricación de puertas.
texts.en:
Wilfredo is a 23 year old, enterprising man. He shares his life with his 24 year old wife, Mireya. They live together in his in-laws’ house. He has been making doors, windows, and other objects from metal for over five years. He does this in the workshop that belongs to his mother-in-law. When he got together with his wife they both decided to work very hard to get the family business ahead. Upon seeing how his father-in-law worked with so much desire and effort, Wilfredo also wants to work with this same drive. His sole purpose is to improve this manufacturing shop. On the other hand, his mother-in-law is in charge of the administration of the business. That is how Wilfredo and his family divide the work. In the future he wishes to set up his own business. He only hopes that his father-in-law’s shop is well established, and that they do not need his help. This is his second loan with MFP. He has always been characterized as being very responsible with his payments. He will use the requested loan to buy materials to complete his work of making doors.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to finish making things from metal

loans.name: Canal De Bendicion 6 Group

texts.en:
Dignorah is the coordinator of her group Canal De Bendicion (Channel of Blessing), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the economy is dominated by the sugarcane harvest and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her common-law husband and their two children.

Dignorah is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling shoes and beauty products by purchasing more merchandise. She will use the profits to improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy Avon beauty products and shoes

loans.name: Cathérine

texts.fr: Née en 1966, S. Cathérine est mariée à HOUANSOU Rufin, un revendeur. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Cathérine s'est installée depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Placodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Cathérine assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Cathérine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et apporter une assistance fianncière à sa famille, Cathérine vend des poissons fumés et des condiments de sauce. Cathérine s'approvisionne à Cotonou. Cathérine a obtenu antérieurement deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire par la vente de ses produits, Cathérine sollicite pour une troisième fois, un appui financier auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1966, Cathérine S. is married to Rufin HOUANSOU, a retailer. The couple has three children, all in school. About ten years ago Cathérine settled down in Placodji, a neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin’s economic capital, where she lives with her husband and their children. Together, Cathérine and her husband look after the family’s various needs. Cathérine never went to school. To support herself and her family financially, Cathérine sells smoked fish and sauce condiments. She gets her stocks in Cotonou. Cathérine has benefited from two previous loans, which were repaid without incident. In order to boost her level of activity and increase her revenues through the sale of her products, Catherine is seeking a third loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase boxes of fresh fish and condiments

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Né le 18 Novembre 1979 à Sikasso, Monsieur S. est marié et père des deux enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Mamassoni, un des quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur S. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au commerce de matériels d’électricités il y a maintenant sept ans. Il y a maintenant deux ans qu’il dispose de sa propre Quincaillerie en face du Centre de Santé Tripano.  Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle (entreprises, particuliers etc)  pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec laquelle il a bénéficié de trois prêts individuels qui ont été  tous correctement remboursés. Il est à noter que  ce troisième prêt fut même  remboursé par anticipation. 
Ainsi ce quatrième prêt lui permettra d’acheter à Bamako, Bobo, Koumassi et Abidjan (respectivement au Mali, en Burkina Faso, au Ghana et en Côte d’Ivoire) 30 cartons de contacteurs, 40 cartons d’ampoules différentes, 15 rouleaux de fil différents, 45 paires de réglettes, 20 paquets de disjoncteurs, etc. 
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 320 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on November 18, 1979 in Sikasso, Mr. S. is a married man and the father of two children. He lives with his family in Mamassoni, an outlying district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run several businesses unsuccessfully, he became introduced to commerce in electrical supplies and equipment seven years ago. For two years now, he has had his own hardware store located opposite the Tripano Health Center. He is much in demand by his customers (enterprises, individuals, etc.) for the quality of his products. To satisfy his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, where he has had three individual loans, which were all repaid properly. It should be noted that the third loan was even repaid in advance. This fourth loan will enable him to buy: 30 boxes of switches, 40 boxes of various bulbs, 15 spools of different wires, 45 pairs of strip lights, 20 packets of circuit breakers, etc., from Bamako, Bobo, Koumassi, and Abidjan (respectively in Mali, Burkina Faso, Ghana, and Cote d'Ivoire). With this loan, he envisions making a monthly profit of 320,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase his working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying electrical supplies for his hardware store

loans.name: Pedro Antonio

texts.es:
El  Sr. Pedro Antonio P. V.  es de la ciudad de San Estanislao, del Barrio Novireta San Blas, tiene 39 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Adela Cuevas con 38 años de edad, Actualmente tienen 2 hijos en edad escolar.
 
       Posee una despensa en su domicilio particular, con clientela formada, tiene buen ingreso, buenas referencias comerciales y personales, señor muy trabajador.
Ademas del negocio con que cuentan ellos también trabajan en agricultura principalmente para el consumo familiar, también tiene vacas lecheras de donde diariamente obtienen leche para consumir
texts.en:
Pedro Antonio P. V. is from the Novireta San Blas neighborhood of the city of San Estanislao. He is 39 years old, and is married to Adela Cuevas, who is 38. They have 2 children who are currently school-aged. They have a store located in their home that has a regular customer base. It generates a good income, and they have good business and personal references as he is a very hardworking man. In addition to this business they also both work in agriculture, mainly to produce for their own consumption. They also have milk cows from which they are able to get milk daily to consume.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, flour, yerba, and other items.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is happily married with five children who all attend school. She has been operating her food stall business for the last 15 years with her husband's support. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Saumu sells food from home to her neighbors and passers-by.

With the Kshs 80,000 loan she wants to purchase one sack of beans, wheat flour, and also renovate her food stall.

Saumu faces the challenge of high competition from other food vendors. She hopes that someday she will open a hotel in a very competitive market. Her aim of joining Yehu is to get a loan and expand her business.

Saumu owns a home with no electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food.

loans.use: To buy one sack of beans, wheat flour, and also renovate her food stall.

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr:
C'est une femme qui est célibataire, mère de 3enfants, le plus âgé a 20ans et le moins âgé a 16ans.Avec son niveau sécondaire, elle s'est lancé dans le commerce du poison salé depuis 1997 avec 100000f de capital.Très stricte dans sa gestion et dans le choix de sa marchandise.
Agée de 38ans, elle veut s'affirmer dans la vente du poisson salé et faire la vente en gros.par jour ,elle vend 35000f et plus quand les vente sont meilleurs.
Si elle a le prêt, elle va achéter 3cartons de poisson sole, 2cartons de poisson thon, 2cartons de poisson morue, 1 sac des champignons et un panier des crévêttes.
Agrandir son activité est son soucis mageur,elle veut aussi avoir les avantages que offrent votre institution  à travers les enseignements reçuent.
pour ses enfants, elle veut assurer leurs avenir et les donnés une bonne éducation scolaire.
D'après son entourage, c' est une bonne femme.
texts.en:
Germaine D. is an unmarried woman and the mother of three children. The oldest is 20 and the youngest is 16 years old. Educated at the high school level, she began selling salted fish in 1997 with a capital sum of 100,000 f. She is very meticulous in her management and in the choice of her merchandise. Age 38, she wants to establish herself as a seller of salted fish and to become a wholesale retailer. Her sales gross 35,000 f per day and more when sales are better. If she gets the loan, she will buy 3 cases of sole, 2 cases of tuna, 2 cases of cod, 1 bag of mushrooms and a basket of shrimp. Her main concern is to expand her business. She also wants to have the advantages that this institution offers through its successful teaching. She wants to ensure the future of her children and to give them a good education. According to her family circle, she is a good woman.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand her sales by purchasing  2 cases of tuna, 2 cases of sole, 2 cases of cod, 1 bag of dried mushrooms and 1 basket of shrimp.

loans.name: Untie

texts.en:
Untie A. is married and has five dependents. She has completed a senior high education. Untie travels to Teshiman to buy bags of maize, tubers of yams, bunches of plantains, and other foods to sell at Abura. Her husband is a laboratory technician. Untie uses her income to help her husband pay for school fees and utility bills. 

Untie will use the loan to purchase additional bags of maize and other foods to meet the increasing demands of her customers.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and other food

loans.name: Flor Maria

texts.es:
Flor de 34 años, vive en el Paraíso de Guayaquil ( zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución). Tiene un gabinete de belleza desde las hace mucho tiempo. 

Para poder mantener a sus dos hijos ella tuvo que invertir su dinero en tijeras, tratamientos y empezar a trabajar de lo que ella había aprendido en un curso de belleza. Con esfuerzo y dedicación ella pudo tener su local y trabajar desde ese tiempo hasta ahora 08h00am hasta las 22h00pm. Pero como el local lo construyo en su casa no tuvo mas dinero para readecuarla y por eso con el préstamo quiere comprar cemento, bloques y piedras. 

Uno de sus sueños es construir mejor su casa ya que es uno de sus sueño darle una mejor vida a sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
Flor, age 34, lives in the paradise of Guayaquil (a periurban zone with an ecology that is breaking down). She has had a beauty salon for a long time. In order to be able to maintain her two children she had to invest her money in scissors and treatments and start to work from what she had learned in a beauty course. With hard work and dedication she was able to have her business and work from 8am to 10pm. But since the shop was built in her home she did not have more money to readapt it and so with this loan she wants to buy cement, blocks and stones. One of her dreams is to build her house better as it is one of her dreams to give her two children a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cement, stone and blocks

loans.name: La Fe 6,7 Group

texts.en:
Dioselina is the coordinator of her group La Fe (The Faith), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest dominates the economy and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her common-law husband and their two children.

Dioselina is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a colmado (general store) by purchasing rice, flour and sugar to sell. She will use the profits to provide for her children's basic needs, including purchasing notebooks. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy rice, flour and sugar

loans.name: Bremilda

texts.es: Bremilda de 46 años de edad, comparte su vida a lado de su hijo Eurles de 20 años en su casa propia. Hace mas de 4 años se dedica en la venta de cerveza, negocio que lo realiza en su propio domicilio, de esa manera le resultó muy rentable. Gracias a los años que ella tiene en la actividad se ha hecho de gran fama en la zona en la que vive, es por ello que cuando los vecinos requieren de la compra de esta bebida para la celebración de cumpleaños, bautizos y otro, siempre recurren a Bremilda quien siempre ofrece los mejores precios y además con facilidades de pago. Además de este negocio, también compró una moto, en la que su hijo lo conduce y trabaja en el transporte público, otras veces lo alquila, es así que obtiene ingresos extras. Ella se siente contenta con el negocio que tiene y espera que sigan prosperando en el futuro. Este es su quinto crédito con MFP y siempre se caracterizó por ser muy responsable con sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará cajas de cerveza a consignación para las próximas fiestas patrias.
texts.en:
Bremilda, age 46, shares her life at the side of her 20 year old son, Burles. They live in her own house. She has been selling beer for over 20 years. The business is in her house. This way it turned out to be very profitable for her. Thanks to the years that she has had this activity, it has developed a great reputation in the area where she lives. That is why when her neighbors need to buy this drink for the celebration of a birthday, baptism or other festivity, they always go to Bremilda. She always offers the best prices and easy payment. In addition to this business, she also bought a motorcycle. Her son drives it and works in public transportation. Other times she rents it out to get extra income. She is happy with the business that she has, and she hopes to keep prospering in the future. This is her fifth loan with MFP. She has always been characterized as being very responsible with her payments. She will use the requested loan to buy crates of beer on consignment for the next national holidays.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cases of beer

loans.name: Ritza Zulema

texts.es:
la sra. Ritza Zulema O. es una mujer luchadora que se dedica a la venta de mangos en diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Choluteca, Ritza se levanta a las 6 de la mañana todos los dias para salir a vender sus mangos y en las tardes compra los del dia siguiente.
doña Ritza es madre de 2 hijos, los tiene estudiando en una escuela publica de el barrio en donde vive.
doña Ritza en sus tiempos libres se dedica a visitar la iglesia,  ella y su esposo trabajan duro para salir adelante con sus hijos.
 
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas mangos al por mayor y asi tener guardados en su casa para no salir a comprar todos los dias, con esto se ahorrara gastos y asi tendra mas ganancias.
texts.en:
Ritza Zulema O. is a hard-working woman who sells mangoes in different areas of the city of Choluteca. Ritza gets up at 6am every day to go sell her mangoes, and in the afternoon she buys mangoes for the next day. She is a mother of two children, who are studying in a public school in her neighbourhood. In her free time Ritza goes to church. She and her husband work hard to get their children ahead. She will use this loan to buy more mangoes wholesale to keep in her home so that she does not have to go out to purchase them every day. With this she will save on costs and also have more earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of mangoes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María Estela M., tiene 44 años de edad, es casada con 4 hijos, de los cuales 2 con estudios terciarios y dos están cursando la primaria. Su marido es empleado y le apoya en todos los emprendimientos que ella decida.
María es confeccionista de alta costura, estudió la profesión en un curso taller en el Instituto Beato Roque González de Santacruz, ubicado en la ciudad de Paraguarí. Empezó a trabajar en el ramo desde el año 1998, con una sola máquina, no le daba abasto para cumplir con toda la clientela ya sea por falta de capital o por falta de maquinarias.
Debido a que necesitaba cumplir con su clientela que con el tiempo se iba acrecentando, optó por recurrir a los créditos de la Fundación Paraguaya y de esa manera pudo comprar las maquinarias necesarias e ir creciendo escalonadamente.
 Hoy día tiene 4 maquinas rectas y otra ovrelock  de 5 hilos; Todas ellas industriales.  Y también cuenta con un empleado que le ayuda en los quehaceres.
texts.en:
María Estela M., age 44, is married with 4 children, of whom 2 are in university and two are in elementary school. Her husband is employed and supports her in all of her endeavours. She is a maker of high fashion. She studied the profession in a workshop course in the Beato Roque Gonzalez de Santacruz Institute, located in the city of Paraguari. She started to work in the industry in 1998, with one single machine, which did not give her the supply to serve all of her customers, either through lack of capital or lack of machines. Since she needed to serve her customer base, which was growing with time, she opted to take out a loan from Fundacion Paraguaya and this way she was able to buy the necessary machines and expand. She now has 4 straight line machines and another 5-threaded overlock machine; they are all industrial machines. She also has an employee who helps her with the work.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of machines for clothes-making

loans.name: Anexo 3 Group

texts.es:
EL grupo Anexo 3 está conformado por tres personas trabajadoras una de ellas es Santa Julia R. M. quien hace cinco años con 500 córdobas cuando el quintal de arroz costaba 300 córdobas inicio su pequeña venta. Este negocio con el tiempo empezó fue surtiendo hasta convertirla en una pulpería pero el sueño de ella es lograr tener una miscelánea. 

Sus compañeras de grupo son Vilma P. Mendosa quien comercializa ropa y CD y Maribel R. Mendosa tiene una pequeña fritanga restaurante popular que consiste en la venta de comida frita. Ella inicio este negocio con la venta de repocheta y fresco el cual por medio de los préstamos fue desarrollando y actualmente sueña con mejorar las instalaciones de su negocio.
texts.en:
The Anexo 3 group is comprised of three hard-working people. One of them is Santa Julia R. M.. Five years ago she used 500 córdobas, when a quintal (46 kg.) of rice cost 300 córdobas, to start a small sales business. In time she stocked this business, and then she converted it into a mini market. But, her dream is to come to have a business selling miscellaneous goods. Vilma P. Mendosa, a colleague in the group, sells clothes and CDs. Maribel R. Medosa, the other colleague in the group, has a popular “fritanga” restaurant, which consists of selling fried food. She started this business selling “repocheta” (Nicaraguan appetizers similar to quesadillas) and soft drinks. The business developed through the loans. She currently dreams of improving her business’s facilities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Basic grains, etc.

loans.name: Maxima Estela

texts.es:
Máxima de 48 años, vive en el Paraíso de Guayaquil ( zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución). Ella tiene dos carros que los alquila para taxis. 

Para poder mantener a sus dos hijas ella tuvo que invertir su dinero en un carro que lo comenzó a maneja su esposo poco a poco con esfuerzo, ellos pudieron tener otro carro para alquilarlo a un taxista. Ahora ella tiene un dos carros y su esposo es guía de la cárcel. Diariamente los carros le producen $ 50.00 diarios. 

Para continuar con sus carros ella quiere comprar llantas ya que están gastadas .Uno de sus sueños es tener una cooperativa de carros y que sus hijas terminen con éxito la universidad.
texts.en:
Máxima, age 48, lives in the paradise of Guayaquil (a periurban zone, with a dissolving ecology). She has two cars which she rents for taxis. In order to maintain her two children she had to invest her money in a car which her husband started to drive. Bit by bit, with hard work, they were able to get another car to rent to a taxi driver. Now she has two cars and her husband is a prison guard. Daily the cars make them $50.00. In order to continue with her cars she wants to buy used tires. One of her dreams is to have a car cooperative and that her children will finish university with success.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: tires

loans.name: Iganga Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
K. Aisha was a dedicated fruit seller before she had a change of mind seven years ago and ventured into what she rationalized would be a more lucrative poultry business.

Like many of her contemporaries, this 40-year-old found the prospect of bearing a hand in any business a fascinating experience. Most of her close acquaintances had entrepreneurial skills and were doing well in business.

As of now, Aisha is eager to cast her mind to the future, knowing how she has strived and gone out of her depth to establish a niche for herself in the local market in Kirinya, Mukono. She attributes her business longevity and all she has achieved to her sense of hard work and determination.

Aisha’s family have also, in the course of the last six years, basked in the glow of any improvement in her circumstances. This happily married mother has laid great store on the education of her children with earnings from her business. In a week, she is able to make ends meet on profits that add up to 200,000 shillings.

Aisha’s future plans are to expand her business even further with this loan. She primarily wants to buy more chickens that she says she will resell in the course of her transactions.

loans.use: To purchase more chicken that she will later resell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen D. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Helen is married and has seven children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She also sells vegetables. Helen has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a  loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This  will be the first loan taken out by Helen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: María Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
El grupo María Auxiliadora lo conforman tres mujeres esforzadas, decididas y emprendedoras una de ellas es Waleska del Rosario R., coordinadora del grupo, ella hace dos años que empezó a comercializar ropa y zapatos con la ayuda de su madre. Esta joven de 21 años sueña con mejorar su negocio y seguir aprendiendo.

Sus compañeras de grupo son María Elena V.  la cual comercializa ropa y zapatos hace tres años y  María Mercedes H. la cual en el 2000 instalo sus pequeña venta la cual ha idop surtiendo y mejorando poco a poco.
texts.en:
Three hard-working and determined women make up the María Auxiliadora Communal Bank. One of them is Waleska del Rosario R., the coordinator of the group. Two years ago she started selling clothes and shoes with help from her mother. This young woman is 21 years old, and she dreams of improving her business and continuing to learn. One of her colleagues in the group is María Elena V., who has been selling clothes and shoes for three years. Her other colleague, María Mercedes H., set up a small sales business in 2000. She has been stocking it and improving it little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothes and shoes

loans.name: Veronica Cecilia

texts.es: Veronica tiene 24 años de edad, vive con su esposo quien se dedidca a piloto de caminiones de carga pesada, tienen 3 hijos de los cuales ninguno va al colegio porque todavía están muy pequeños, ella inició su negocio hace 8 años asociada con su suegrapero lamentablemente la suegra murio y ahora el negocio lo trabaja solo ella, ella vende ponchos, cubrecamas, y vajillas, esta mercadería la compra en tapachula y viaja 2 veces al mes, pero debido a la demanda de sus clientes ella necesita más capital para poder invertir más y tener mas ganancias, el sueño a corto plazo de Veronica es ampliar sus ventas para poder tener un local y surtir más productos, y el sueño a lasrgo plazo es ver a sus hijos convertidos en hombres de bien y mujers de éxito, tanto en lo espiritual como en lo material.
texts.en:
Verónica is 24 years old. She lives with her husband, who is a heavy cargo truck driver. They have three children; none of them go to school because they are still too young. Eight years ago she started her business in association with her mother-in-law. Sadly, her mother-in-law died, and now she works alone. She sells ponchos, bedspreads, and dishes. She buys this merchandise in Tapachula. She goes there two times a month. However, due to her customer demand, she needs more money to be able to invest more and have more income. Veronica’s short term dream is to expand her sales in order to be able to have a place and stock more products. Her long term dream is to see her children become good and successful adults as much in the spiritual way as in the material way.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest more in her business

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María es una alegre y trabajadora mujer de 46 años de edad, comparte su vida con su pareja y su hijo Jesús de 11 años en su casa propia. Hace mas de dos años se dedica en la venta de ceviche (plato típico peruano), en un puesto que tiene instalado en el exterior de su casa. En un inicio cuando obtuvo su primer crédito, pudo mejorar su negocio y ahora prepara otros platillos de acuerdo a la cantidad de pedidos que tiene. Desde entonces debe preparar previamente los alimentos que le son solicitados, disfruta mucho de esta actividad por que debe ser minuciosa en el momento de la preparación, además es exigente para obtenga la sazón exacta que a todos sus clientes gustan. En un futuro ella quiere seguir mejorando su negocio, con el tiempo espera tener su propio restaurante. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP, por lo tanto asegura que seguirá siendo muy responsable con los pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará ingredientes al por mayor para así economizar y lograr mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Maria, age 46, is a happy working woman. She lives, together with her husband and her 11 year old son Jesús, in her own home. For more than 2 years, Maria has been running a business selling ceviche (a typical Peruvian dish) from a stand she had built next to her house. When Maria obtained her first loan, she was able to expand her business and now prepares many other dishes requested by her customers, in addition to ceviche. She really enjoys the meticulous process of food preparation and the challenge of working to obtain precise flavors that all of her customers will enjoy. In the future, Maria wants to continue expanding her business and in time hopes to have her own restaurant. This is her second loan with MFP, and she has assured that she will continue being very responsible with the payments. With the credit that Maria is requesting, she plans to buy ingredients wholesale in order to save money and increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kaplan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products and ingredients for food preparation.

loans.name: Zandra

texts.en:
Zandra L. is from the village of Paradise, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 44 years old. Zandra is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Zandra operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing, like skirts, t-shirts and blouses, in the local community. Zandra has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Zandra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Zandra is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Zandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Jolynida

texts.en: Jolynida P. is from the village of Paradise, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 38 years old. Jolynida is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jolynida runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products. Jolynida has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Jolynida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jolynida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Jolynida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jolynida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.fr:
N. Leonidas est l’un des membres de Groupes Solidaires ABISHYIZEHAMWE, est née en 1977. Il est marié, il a 2 enfants et une personne en charge. Son premier née  a 4 ans  et son dernier a 3 ans. N. Leonidas a fait 6ans d’école primaire et 2ans post primaire  Il est membre actif de ce groupe solidaire et  manifeste un esprit d’équipe pour l’expansion de leur business diversifié dont tous les membres font le petit commerce. 

Il a commencé ses petits commerces des habits pour hommes et femmes depuis 2005 avec un capital initial de 70.000Frw en commercialisant des vêtements. Mais grâce a l’ACB sa qu’elle a amélioré ses activités de commerce parce qu’il est prés à solliciter un prêt de supérieur pour pouvoir augmenter son chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
Leonidas N. is one of the members of the solidarity group Abishyizehamwe. He is born in 1977. He is married, has two children and one other family member in his care. His oldest child is four years old, and his youngest is three years old. Leonidas has had six years of primary school and two years of secondary school. HE is an active member of the solidarity group and shows a team spirit, motivated to expand the diversified types of business the members are engaged in. His line of business is selling clothing for men or women, something he started to do in 2005 with a starting capital of 70,000 Rwandan francs. Thanks to ACB his enterprise has picked up, and he is ready to request a larger loan in order to achieve a higher level of revenue.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing men's and women's clothing for retailing

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es: Isabel C., es casa tiene 2 hijos, es una mujer emprendedora ella lucha junto a su esposo para darle educación a sus hijos ya que estna en edad escoalr. Isabel se dedica a su negocio en sus ratos libres borda preciosos Güipiles de Patzun, también se dedica a la venta de frutas, esta muy contenta porque ha obtenido buenas ganancias. Solicita el crédito para comprar güipiles y material para hacerlos y también comprar trajes de bebes.
texts.en:
Isabel C. is married and has two children. She is an enterprising woman who struggles along with her husband in order to give their children an education. The children are now school age. Isabel devotes herself to her business in her free time. She embroiders precious “Güipiles” (embroidered blouses) from Patzun. She also sells fruit. She is very happy because she has gotten good earnings. She is requesting a loan to buy güipiles and material to make them. She will also buy baby clothes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more merchandise to increase the earnings

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda R. is from the village of Kilikili, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 45 years old. Linda is married and has five children. To make a living, Linda runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Linda has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Linda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Linda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Linda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Por La Gracia De Dios Group

texts.es:
Johana Isabel Cortez Morales, María Mercedes R. García y Yadira Elizabeth Cortez Morales tres mujeres joviales, emprendedoras y esforzadas quienes conforman el grupo Por la Gracia de Dios. La coordinadora del grupo es la señora Cortez Morales se dedica a comercializar de todo un poco desde pupusas, elotes, cigarro, dulces, chiverías según comento.

Ella desde temprana edad se dedica a este tipo de comercio ya que ella le ayudaba a su madre a comercializar. El sueño de ella es ser millonaria eso dijo entre risas.

Sus compañeros de grupo son María Mercedes R. García tiene una pequeña pulpería desde hace seis años y Jadira Elizabeth Cortez Morales se dedica al comercio de ropa.
texts.en:
Johana Isabel Cortez Morales, María Mercedes R. García, and Yadira Elizabeth Cortez Morales are three cheerful, enterprising, and hard-working women. They comprise the Por la Gracia de Dios (By the Grace of God) group. Mrs. Cortez Morales is the coordinator of the group. She says that she sells a little bit of everything from “pupusas” (flatbread stuffed with meat, cheese, or vegetables) to beans, cigarettes, sweets, and yogurt. She started this type of work at a young age because she helped her mother sell. She said with laughter that her dream is to be a millionaire. One of her colleagues in the group is María R. García. She has had a small mini market for six years. Their other colleague, Jadira Elizabeth Cortez Morales, sells cloths.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Various products

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth S. is from the village of Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 44 years old. Lilibeth is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lilibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lilibeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:
