loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase necessary materials for a wedding

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena O. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 46 years-old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 16 years.

Elena joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elena is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farming materials. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training which is provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farming materials.

loans.name: Lamulatu

texts.en:
N. Lamulatu is 21 years-old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  Lamulatu has a business managing a retail store, which sells various small goods, in Kyotera.  Lamulatu has had her retail business for approximately one-and-a-half years.

To expand her business, Lamulatu is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy goods to resell and obtain more inventory for her retail shop.  Lamulatu hopes to expand her business and gain more clients in order to generate profits for her family.  

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. First, the ELA program provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer youth a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future and to target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
N. Ruth is 18 years-old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is married and has one child who is seven months old.  Ruth has a business running a retail and grocery shop which sells small goods and food items in Kyotera.  

To expand her business, Ruth is requesting a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more inventory and food  which Ruth will sell at her shop and grocery.  Ruth hopes to expand her business and sell more types of items which can draw more customers and benefit her and her family. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. loans.use: To purchase more retail and food goods.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 32 years-old and married with three school-aged children. She grows hogs for fattening and sale. She has been involved in hog-raising for more than eight years. Out of her income from the pigs, she was able to start a small sari-sari store where she sells food and daily use products. One of her wishes for the future is to have her three children finish college and find appropriate jobs for themselves.

Jenny joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenny has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jenny is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jenny from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve her business.

texts.en: Eduardo F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 51 years old, married and has 5 children. He still has children who go to school and he does his best to sustain their education. To make a living, Eduardo owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. He also tills a one-hectare rice field. He says that his farm can produce 80 sacks of rice. He hopes to improve his business so he could also earn better and sustain his family. Eduardo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eduardo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Eduardo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed, baby livestock to raise and sell in future, and also farm inputs (fertilizers, etc.). This loan will be the third loan taken out by Eduardo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. loans.name: Raya

texts.en: Raya M. is a math teacher with 30 years of experience teaching in the local school. She lives in a small city called Agarak in one of the remote South regions of Armenia, Meghri. Unfortunately, a teacher’s salary is not enough to make ends meet for a family of four: 26-year-old son, husband and mother-in-law. In the city there is a high unemployment rate, but a farm business helps the family have some stable income. Both husband and son are involved in their small farm, and for a start they already have some livestock. With the requested loan the family plans to increase the livestock and purchase cattle food.

loans.use: Increasing the livestock and purchasing cattle food

loans.name: Katsaka

texts.en:
M. is a married woman with three children who all attend school.  She has been operating her green vegetable business for the last three years and sells from home to her neighbors.  She also gets another source of livelihood from her husband's salary.

With the 20,000 KES (her second loan), she wants to start a charcoal business by purchasing five sacks of charcoal and paying for her business permit.  M. faces the main challenge of transportation.  She hopes that someday she will open another branch and supply to a large market.

She decided to join Yehu to get a loan and modify her business.  She rents a house with electricity but does not have piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bill and school fees.

loans.use: To buy five sacks of charcoal and pay for business permit.

Rejina is 21 years old and is married to a husband who is an electrician. She has no children yet and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent. loans.name: Augustine

texts.fr: H. Augustine est née le 05 Mai 1970 à Godomey, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi au Bénin. Mariée à TCHENADON Pierre, Augustine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Augustine habite le quartier Cocotomey dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différentes charges familiales. Augustine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Augustine vend du charbon de bois à son domicile. Augustine s’approvisionne à Cocotomey. Augustine exerce cette activité depuis quinze ans  et a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Augustine a bien effectué le remboursement de ce crédit. Face à la demande de plus de plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Augustine désire augmenter son stock de produits et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est pour cette raison que Augustine sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Augustine H. was born May 5, 1970 in Godomey, which is in the Abomey Calavi commune of Benin. She is married to Pierre Tchenadon. Augustine has three children, all of whom are in school. Augustine hasn't been to school. Augustine's family has lived in the Cocotomey quarter of Abomey Calavi for about ten years. Together, the couple manages the needs of the household. To meet her family's needs, Augustine sells charcoal from her home. She buys her coal stock in Cocotomey. She has had this business for about fifteen years and has received one previous loan from ALIDé. Augustine repaid her first loan on time. Now she has more clients and Augustine would like to increase her coal stock to meet their needs. This is why Augustine is seeking a second loan.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of coal.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: N. Justine is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is single and has two children. Justine has a business managing a retail shop in Kyotera that sells food and other items. She has had her retail store for approximately two years. To expand her business, Justine is requesting a loan of 150,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more items to stock in her retail store. Justine hopes to expand the number of clients her retail store serves and generate more profits to support her young family. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive micro-finance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional micro-finance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in micro-finance.

loans.use: To stock more retail items in her shop

texts.en: Javid A. is a 40-year-old merchant who sells different kinds of food products in the small village of Saatli. Javid is married and has 2 daughters. He believes one day he could have his own shop.

loans.name: Rose

texts.fr: G. Rose est née le 23 Août 1980 et est mariée à KOUNTE Côme, un chauffeur. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a environs cinq ans que la famille s’est installée au quartier Bazounkpa à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rose vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Rose n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Depuis près de quatre ans, Rose mène comme activité, la vente de produits cométiques et de mèches à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Rose exerce comme activité la vente de divers produits (liqueurs, couscous, savons, conserves de sardine, huile végétale, mayonnaise, papier hygiénique, sucre, riz, etc.) dans sa boutique à son domicile. Cette activité génère à Rose des revenus l’aidant à gagner sa vie. Rose achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo. Rose a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements. Rose désire agrandir sa boutique et accroître sa clientèle, pour se faire plus de profits ; raison pour laquelle Rose sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Rose G. was born on 23 August 1980, and is married to Côme KOUNTE, a professional driver. The couple have three children who are all attending school. The family settled in the Bazounkpa neighborhood of Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin) approximately 5 years ago. Rose helps her husband and together, they cover the economic needs of their family. Rose only attended primary school. For the last four years, she has been selling cosmetic and hair products from her home. As a second source of income, she also sells a variety of products (liquors, couscous, soaps, sardines, vegetable oil, mayonnaise, toilet paper, sugar, rice, etc) from her home. The revenue from this activity allows Rose to live her life. She purchases her products from Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, as well as from Lomé, in Togo. Rose previously received a loan from ALIDé, and re-paid the loan on time. She is asking for a second loan in order to enlarge her store and attract more customers in order to make more profits.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase 10 boxes of sugar, liquor, canned goods, soaps, hair extensions, two bags of rice and cosmetic products

loans.name: Heyran

texts.en: Heyran M. is a 57-year-old entrepreneur who has been involved in the poultry business for the last 12 years. She is married and has four children. Heyran sells chicken and geese to the local cafes and once a month at the livestock bazaar. Her monthly income is about 150-200 AZN. Heyran also keeps cows for milk and dairy products for her family. She would like to expand her livestock business, so she applied for a 600 AZN loan to purchase one milking cow and more poultry.

loans.use: purchase one milking cow and more poultry

loans.name: Jennifer Njoki

texts.en:
Jennifer Njoki is a 60-year-old married lady and the mother of four children between the ages of 16 and 27.  Only the last born is still in school. The others are working; the first as a counselor, the second as a cook and messenger, and the third working for Kenya motors.

Jennifer operates a food kiosk and she also sells grocery items in the same makeshift stall. She serves tea with snacks like sweet potatoes and doughnuts to her customers who are residents of her area of business in Kiambu area.  The grocery business has items like sweet potatoes, tomatoes, onions and so on.  She is able to make a profit of about $187 per month.

Jennifer was introduced to KADET by staffers who were conducting a marketing initiative in the area. She has applied for her third loan which she will use to expand her business by adding things like charcoal, groundnuts, beans and peas to sell.

She would like to see her business expand more and give her more profit, which she would use to educate all her children, and if possible send them abroad for further studies. She believes that her hard work and faithfulness will get her there.

loans.use: To expand her food stall to sell items like charcoal and groundnuts

loans.name: Kiganda Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
Three years is the time that 25-year-old, affable and industrious T. Sarah has operated her stone quarrying business in Kireka, Mukono. She is married with one child and has used the profits from this business to cater for her family’s welfare.

Sarah was operating a salon prior to establishing this business and, with savings from her salon business, she set forth on this business. She has had to summon up a lot of hard work and dedication for her business to make some much-needed headway. In a month, she makes profits totaling up to 240,000 shillings. she also makes side profits from her retail shop.

Sarah is planning on building a family house with an anticipated improvement in her circumstances in the near future. She carries conviction that this is going to materialize with the improvement measures she is planning on bringing to bear after she gets this loan.

The proceeds from this loan, she says, will go into purchasing another piece of land where she reckons she will be able to get more stones, thus expanding her quarrying activities. With this happening, she foresees better revenues for her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase another piece of land to get more stones for her business

loans.name: O. Marie-Madeleine

texts.fr: D. O. Marie-Madeleine est née en 1975 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Marie-Madeleine est mariée à ALAGBE Antoine et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Marie-Madeleine vit depuis sept ans environs, au quartier Hindé à Cotonou, avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple subvient ensemble aux  différents besoins de la famille. Marie-Madeleine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis huit ans, Marie-Madeleine vend des vêtements tous cousus à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, ce qui lui permet de contribuer aux dépenses familiales. Marie-Madeleine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa et à Lomé au Togo. Marie-Madeleine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés, malgré sa récente maladie. Aujourd’hui, Marie-Madeleine désire renforcer son activité et augmenter ses ventes. C’est donc pour augmenter son stock de produits que Marie-Madeleine sollicite un cinquième prêt.
texts.en:
Marie-Madeleine D. was born in 1975 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is maried to Antoine ALAGBE and is the mother of two children, all of whom attend school. Marie-Madeleine has lived for the past seven years in the Hindé neighborhood of Cotonou with her husband and children. The couple address the family's needs together. Marie-Madeleine did not attend school. For the past eight years, she has been selling handmade clothes at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, which allows her to contribute to the family expenses. She stocks up at Dantokpa et in Lomé, in Togo. Marie-Madeleine previously received four loands from ALIDé, which she all repaid on time, despite her recent illness. Today, Marie-Madeleine would like to increase her sales. She is asking for a fifth loan in order to increase the stock of products she can offer her customers.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing

loans.name: Massouratou

texts.fr: A. Massouratou est née le 02 Décembre 1976 à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à HOUESSOU Raymond, un vitrier, Massouratou n’a pas encore d’enfant, mais a un enfant à sa charge et qui est scolarisé. Massouratou vit avec sa famille à Djeffa depuis sept ans environs. Massouratou assure avec son mari les différentes charges familiales. Massouratou n’a pas été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Massouratou vend du charbon de bois et des fagots de bois à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Massouratou vend des céréales et produits vivriers. Massouratou achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Kétou au Bénin. Massouratou exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans environs, et a déjà bénéficié de trois prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Massouratou voudrait élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est pour y parvenir que Massouratou sollicite pour une quatrième fois, un appui financier de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Massouratou A. was born on 2 December 1976 in Djeffa in the commune of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. She is married to Raymond HOUESSOU, a glass cutter, and although they don't have any children of their own yet, she is responsible for one child who is currently attending school. Massouratou has been living with her family in Djeffa for approximately seven years. Together with her husband, they care for the different family expenses. Massouratou did not attend school. To cover her needs and those of her family, she sells wood charcoal and firewood from her home. As a secondary source of income, Massouratou also sells grains and food products. She purchases her materials in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, as well as in Ketou, another city in Benin. Massouratou has undertaken this activity for about four years, and has already benefitted from three loans, all of which were reimbursed in a timely manner. Massouratou would like to continue to increase the level of commercial activity and be able to better respond to the requests from her customers. She is thus asking for a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase charcoal and firewood

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: A. Jeanne est née en 1965 et est mariée à AFOTON, un pêcheur. Jeanne a un enfant qui est scolarisé. Depuis une vingtaine d’année, Jeanne habite le quartier Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Jeanne vit avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple supporte ensemble les divers charges familiales. Jeanne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Jeanne est dans la restauration. Jeanne prépare en effet, de la pâte de maïs accompagnée de différentes sauces qu’elle vend à la devanture de sa maison. Jeanne s’approvisionne au marché de Houègbo au Bénin. Jeanne  exerce cette activité depuis quinze ans environs. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu déjà six prêts de ALIDé, prêts qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Dans le but de développer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Jeanne sollicite un septième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Jeanne A. was born in 1965 and is married to Mr. Afoton, a fisherman. Jeanne has one child who is in school. Jeanne's family has been living in the Lokokoukoumè quarter of the Sèmè-Podji commune for about twenty years. Together, the couple manages the household's needs. Jeanne has not been to school. Jeanne runs a food service business. She makes maize pasta with different sauces, and sells the dishes from the front of her house. Jeanne buys her supplies at the Houègbo market in Benin. She has been doing this for about fifteen years. She has already received six loans from ALIDé, all of which she repaid on time. She wants to build her business and meet the needs of an ever growing number of customers, so Jeanne is seeking a seventh loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and condiments

loans.name: Alice Wairimu

texts.en:
Alice Wairimu is a 33-year-old single lady who is also a mother to two children age 10 and 2 1/2 years old. She operates a retail shop in an area called Riabai, which is on the outskirts of Nairobi. She sells items like sweets, soft drinks, flour, rice and others in her retail shop and she normally gets a profit of about $225 per month.  Her business is two months old in this area and her customers are mainly the residents of that area. 

Alice was introduced to KADET by another client and she joined, although she has a previous credit history with another Micro-Finance Institution. She has applied for her second loan which she plans to use to add a stock of animal feeds for resale in her retail shop.

She hopes to be able to get enough profits to educate her children through high school and college, and if possible to live abroad. She is a very ambitious lady.

loans.use: to stock animal feed for resale

loans.name: Aitbubu's Group

texts.en: Aitbubu K. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and breeds livestock. Her husband provides welding services at the hydroelectric station and when he has free time he helps Aitbubu with her business. In 2008, with the initial investment of 12,000 soms, Aitbubu bought eight farm animals and started to breed livestock. Now she has fifteen farm animals and, selling some of them after fattening, she makes 8,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Aitbubu wants to purchase seven farm animals for breeding. In the future she plans to open a pharmacy. Talantbek M., 39, is married and has four children: two sons and his older daughter are students and his second daughter is not yet in school. Eight years ago, with the initial investment of 2,000 soms, Talantbek bought three farm animals and started to breed livestock. Now he has eight farm animals and, selling some of them at a higher price after fattening, Talantbek makes 7,000 soms per month. He applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase ten sheep in order to increase the number of his livestock. Parida M. is the treasurer of the group; she is 43 and divorced with four children. In order to make money, two years ago she started to breed livestock. She started with an initial investment of 1,600 soms and, with that money, she bought two farm animals. In two years, she has increased the number of her livestock to ten and now, selling some livestock at a higher price after fattening, she makes 6,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase four farm animals in order to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she plans to save some money and start building a house for her children. Uulkyz K., 41, is married; her husband is an artist. They have two sons and a daughter: the first son and the daughter are students and the second son is not yet in school. In 2001, with an initial investment of 7,000 soms, Uulkyz bought a calf and started to breed livestock. Now she has nine farm animals and, selling some of them at a higher price after fattening, she makes 10,000 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase five farm animals in order to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she plans to open a poultry farm. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase seven farm animals for breeding

loans.name: Mariane

texts.fr: K. Mariane est née en 1974 à Missérété, dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. Mariane est mariée à OGOUGBE Philippe, un chauffeur. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Mariane s’est installée depuis environs sept ans au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle réside avec son mari et ses enfants. Mariane assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Mariane n’est pas allée à l’école. Depuis cinq ans, Mariane mène comme activité la vente de nourriture (haricot accompagnée de pain et de poissons) à Cotonou, ce qui lui permet de se nourrir et d’assurer un temps soit peu les besoins de ses enfants. Mariane s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu quatre crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. La demande de la clientèle de Mariane se fait de plus en plus nombreuse. C’est donc pour renforcer son activité et augmenter le volume de ses ventes pour se faire plus de revenus, que Mariane sollicite un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Mariane K. was born in 1974 at Missérété, in the Ouémé region of Bénin.Mariane is married to Philippe Ogougbe, a driver. The couple has four children all of whom attend school. For about the last seven years Mariane has been living with her husband and her children in the Finagnon neighbourhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She shares the various family expenses with her husband.Mariane did not go to school. For the last five years Mariane has been making a living by selling food (beans eaten with bread and fish) at Cotonou, this gives her the means to feed herself and to support a small part of her children’s needs.Mariane buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a former client of ALIDé, where she obtained four credits all of which she repaid on time.Mariane’s customers are asking for more products. Therefore it is in order to develop her activity and increase the volume of her sales to improve her income, that Mariane is requesting a new loan

Translated from French by Barbara Belli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of cereals (beans etc.) seasoning and fish.

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr: A. Béatrice est née en 1967 et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Béatrice est une veuve. Béatrice vit seule avec son enfant au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis cinq ans environs. Béatrice assure seule les différentes charges de son enfant. Béatrice n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de son enfant, Béatrice vend des condiments, des céréales (riz, etc.) et divers produits (galettes d'arachide, farine de manioc, huile, conserve, lait, etc.) à son domicile. Béatrice achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Sékou et à Dogbo au Bénin. Béatrice a déjà douze ans d’expérience dans l’exercice de cette activité. C’est la première fois que Béatrice sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle, et donc se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Beatrice A. was born in 1967 and is the mother of a child who attends school. Beatrice is a widow. She has been living alone with her child in the neighborhood of Finagnon in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, for approximately five years. She takes care of her child by herself. Beatrice did not attend school. To support herself and her child, she sells condiments, cereals (rice, etc.) and various products (peanut flatcakes, cassava flour, oil, canned goods, milk, etc.) from her home. She gets her stocks in Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and in Sékou and Dogbo, also located in Benin. Beatrice already has twelve years of experience in this activity. She is seeking financial assistance with ALIDé for the first time in order to strengthen her business, expand her customer base and increase her profits.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments (tomatoes, onions, peppers, etc.) and bags of rice, cassava flour, etc.

loans.name: Fazil

texts.en: Fazil Q., 44 years old, rents a place where he runs a café or tea house, as it called in Azerbaijan. He is married and has three children. His monthly income is 150-200 AZN. He serves about 50 to 60 people a day and works from 6 a.m. until 1 a.m. especially in the summertime. He would like to improve conditions in his café and purchase new chairs and tables. Fazil wishes to build his own café in the next several years.

loans.use: purchase new chairs and tables

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter J. is currently in the business of selling earrings and necklaces and is requesting a loan to stock more necklaces to sell.  Peter is 37 years old and is married to a driver. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a beauty shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more necklaces to sell

loans.name: Nadine

texts.fr: A. Nadine est née le 09 Mars 1983 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Nadine est mariée à DAAGBO Nicodème et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Nadine vit avec son enfant à Cocotomey, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la famille. Nadine n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a près de huit ans que Nadine vend des mèches et des tissus à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Nadine vend des canaris, ce qui lui permet de se faire plus de revenus. Nadine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo. C’est la première fois que Nadine sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
Nadine A. was born 9 March 1983 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Nadine is married to Nicodème DAAGBO and is the mother of one child attending school. She lives with her child in Cocotomey, in the Abomey Calavi district. The couple shares the various family expenses. Nadine has only attended primary school. For the past eight years she has been selling hair extensions and clothing fabrics from her home. As a side business, Nadine also sells canaris (earthenware vessels), which provides an additional source of income. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and also in Lomé, Togo. This is the first time Nadine has requested a loan from ALIDé, with the intention of boosting her level of activity and increasing her turnover.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy canaris (earthenware vessels) and hair extensions

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella G. is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Stella is 50 years old and is married. She has nine children and two of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Alet

texts.en:
Alet D. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize flour, rice and beans, and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell.  Alet is 39 years old and married to a soldier. She has three children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine L. is currently in the business of selling fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell.  Christine is 31 years old and is married to a policeman. She has two children and they both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora S. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell.  Flora is 42 years old and is married to a peasant. She has four children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Atma

texts.en:
Atma A. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Atma is 49 years old and is a widow.   She has seven children and only one child goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Adjo Julienne

texts.fr: F. Adjo Julienne est née en 1975 au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Julienne est mariée à BANKOLE Simon, un commerçant, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Depuis près de onze ans,  Julienne s’est installée avec sa famille au quartier Cocotomey, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Julienne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a environs cinq ans que Julienne mène comme activité, la vente de produits de quincaillerie, par le système de distribution. Julienne s’approvisionne à Lomé et au Ghana, deux Etats voisins du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et d’accroître sa quantité d’approvisionnement, Julienne sollicite pour une première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Adjo Julienne F. was born in 1975 in Togo, a country neighbouring Benin. Julienne is married to Simon BANKOLE, a merchant, and is the mother of three children, all attending school. She settled 11 years ago with her family in the Cocotomey borough of the Abomey Calavi district. The couple shares various family expenses. Julienne has not attended school. For the past five years she has been retailing general hardware articles through the distribution system. She gets her supplies from Lomé in Togo and from Ghana, two countries adjacent to Benin. Wishing to bolster her activity and increase her stock supply, Julienne is requesting for the first time a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy general hardware items

loans.name: Margaret Nduta

texts.en:
Margaret Nduta is a lady who is married to Joseph Kimani and is the mother of four children aged between 23 to 30 years. Two of her children are casual laborers with some industrial companies while the other two are college students.

Margaret is a farmer and she has been practicing farming for the last twenty years. She specializes in both dairy and vegetable farming and later sells the produce and milk to her neighbors who are her customers and also supplies the same to a farmers’ cooperative society near her. She is able to take home a profit of Kshs 14,000 every month.

Margaret was introduced to KADET by one of its staff who had been conducting a promotional outreach within her area. Margaret then formed a group with her neighbors and she has now applied for a loan of Kshs 50,000 which she will use to extend her cattle shed to accommodate more cattle.

Margaret would like to take all her children abroad for further studies and also own a modest house, drive a good car, and make the best out of life for herself and her family. She describes herself as modest with a lot of ambition.

loans.use: To extend her cattle shed to accomodate more cattle

loans.name: Agakindo Group

texts.fr:
La cheftaine du groupe Agakindo est Hyacinthe M., alors que Mr. Jean de Dieu M. a été choisi pour créer le profil de ce groupe. Hyacinthe est celle qui a levé la main, et Jean de Dieu M. est le deuxième à la gauche.
M. Jean de Dieu, née à Bugesera l’Est du pays en 1975, marié avec sept enfants,son ainé a 11 ans et son cadet a 2 ans et il a étudié l’école primaire. Il vit avec sa famille à Sake Bugesera. Trois enfants vont à l’école.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé AGAKINDO,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont agri-éleveurs et ils se garantissent mutuellement, M. et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en payant les minervals pour leurs enfants. M., lui fait  le commerce de boutique, le prêt lui permettra d'acheter le sucre, du sel, savons pour augmenter son capital. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour vente de ses produits. Une partie des intérêts est réinvesti,une autre est épargné afin de préparer l’avenir.
texts.en:
The leader of the Agakindo group is Hyacinthe Mikantibazi, but Mr. Jean de Dieu M. was chosen to create this group's Kiva profile. Hyacinthe is the person raising her hand, and Jean de Dieu M. is the second from the right. Jean de Dieu M. was born in Bugesera -in the East part of the country- in 1975. He is married with seven children, of whom the eldest is 11 and the youngest 2 years old. He went to school at the primary level and lives with his family in Sake Bugesera. Three of his children attend school. He belongs to a solidarity group called AGAKINDO, whose members are mainly farmers and guarantee mutual support within the group. M. and his group work to improve their families’ living conditions and pay their children’s tuition fees. M. for his part operates a store. The loan will enable him to buy sugar, salt, and soap to increase his working capital. In fact, the group has contracted a loan within the Amasezerano Community Banking association for the sale of their products. Part of the loan interests are reinvested, and the remainder is put into savings in preparation for future needs. Concerning the group A group loan means that each member takes a share of the loan and makes use of it in their business. The advantage lies in that the group guarantees each member’s individual loan so that if a group member is unable to honor his commitments, the whole group will reimburse in his place.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soap, salt and sugar for retail sales in his shop.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a 46-year-old lady and a mother to four children. She lives in Masindi, Uganda. Margret is a widow, meaning she is the alpha and omega of her family in terms of welfare and education, since nearly all her children are school-going. She says, however, that she can handle the challenges through hard work and commitment.

Margret currently lives in a rented home and operates a beauty salon in which she offers training to those interested in choosing beauty as their business. She also sells cosmetics in her salon, a business she has operated for twelve years. She started as a market vendor selling tomatoes, then sold used clothing before she worked in some one else’s salon, a move that inspired her to start her own salon.

Margret says, however, that the ever-increasing cost of rent, a license and electricity bills are some of the issues posing her business challenges. She dreams of starting up her own beauty school and selling cosmetics wholesale.

This is Margret’s ninth loan from HOFOKAM and she is to use the loan funds to purchase cosmetics and braids to sell in her beauty salon.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and braids to sell in her beauty salon

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Lomé au Togo, K. Marie est mariée à AMANVI Paul, un chauffeur. Marie n’a pas encore d’enfant, mais a un enfant à sa charge. Il y a près de deux ans que Marie et son mari se sont installés au quartier Cocotomey, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Marie n’est jamais allée à l’école. Il y a plus d’un an que Marie vend du maïs, du riz, et de façon secondaire, des condiments de sauce à son domicile. Marie achète ses produits à Adja au Mono, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Marie a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement dudit crédit. Marie désire accroître son activité et ouvrir un point de vente autre que celui du domicile, pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu. C’est la raison pour laquelle Marie sollicite un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Lomé in Togo, Marie K. is married to Paul AMANVI, a driver. Marie has no children of her own, but takes care of one child. Two years ago, she and her husband settled in the Cocotomey borough of the Abomey Calavi district. The couple shares responsibility for the various family expenses. Marie has never attended school. For the past year she has been selling corn, rice, and -to a lesser extent- food condiments from her home. She gets her products from Adja in the Mono area, and from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Marie has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which she promptly repaid. She wants to increase her activity and open up a point of sales other than her home, to increase both turnover and revenue. This is why she is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy five 100-kilo bags of corn, and five bags of rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: stockpile beans, cassava flour, and vegetable oil

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria S. is currently in the business of selling dresses and bedsheets at her shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets to sell. Victoria is 32 years old and is married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Victoria hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sheet metal to make metal doors

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock up on merchandise to better supply her grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking up on cereals for resale

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a 48-year-old woman and the single mother of six children whom she looks after in a rented home in Masindi, Uganda. She says she wants to have her own residential home in the near future.

Margret sells local brew and has been doing so for the last twenty-four years now. At this stage, she wants to have a bigger and more organized place to house her pub business as she seeks to grow the business for more income for her family. Her local brew is hugely marketable for a certain tribe who cherish it so much more than any other drink.

This is Margret’s loan from HOFOKAM with which she is to buy millet for making more local brew to sell in her pub.

loans.use: To purchase millet for making more local brew to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy meat and fish and stock up on beverages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy, install and operate a corn mill

loans.name: Nabieu

texts.en:
Nabieu is a hardworking and very determined businessman. His business centre is located along Rogbaneh Road which is one of the busy Streets in Makeni. He is married to an active businesswoman and has two dependents. Mr. Nabieu was initially financed by his brother and began trading in slippers, which he has now done for thirty-three years.

How to cope with the high transportation costs and frequent increase in wholesale prices of slippers he trades in, is the major challenge Nabieu is faced with. He needs a loan to expand his business.

Nabieu intends to use the additional income generated from this  loan to further invest in his busines and educate his child to university level.

loans.use: To buy additional plastic shoes to sell

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
In the current world today, everybody ought to be very hardworking to make ends meet for a better living. That’s what Harriet, a mother of three, says as she grinds groundnuts (peanuts) for her clients in Masindi, Uganda. Her husband is also a businessman.

Harriet sells groundnuts, beans, and also has a grinding machine for groundnuts, a business which has a market because people are relying on the grinders rather than pounding groundnuts themselves manually. She has been in the business for six years and still hopes to add more grinding machines for increased income.

Having started with only a grinding machine, Harriet now offers a stock of groundnuts for sale. This is Harriet’s third loan from HOFOKAM and she intends to purchase more groundnuts to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy women's hair extensions and weaves

loans.name: Mahinou

texts.fr: D. Mahinou est née en 1973 et est mariée à OWINSE Amadji, un menuisier. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis une quinzaine d’année au quartier Akpakpa Dodomé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mahinou aide son mari à subvenir aux différents besoins de la famille. Pour y arriver, Mahinou vend depuis une dizaine d’année, du poisson et des condiments à son domicile. Mahinou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. En vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de se faire plus de revenus pour assurer un bon train de vie à ses enfants, Mahinou sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
Mahinou D. was born in 1973 and is married to Amadji OWINSE, a carpenter. The couple have three children, all of whom attend school. The family has lived for the past 15 years in the Akpakpa Dodomé neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Mahinou helps her husband take care of the family's needs. To do this, she has been selling fish and condiments from her home for the past 12 years. Mahinou replenishes her stock in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is an established client of ALIDé, and previously received three loans, all of which were reimbursed. She is asking for a fourth loan in order to increase her level of commercial activity and her profits, in order to provide a better standard of living for her children.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fresh fish

loans.name: Rosine

texts.fr: H. Rosine est née en 1978 et est mariée à FADEGNON Henri, un maçon. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Depuis dix sept ans, Rosine habite le quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, avec son mari et ses enfants. Rosine vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges familiales, grâce au revenu de son activité. Rosine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a une douzaine d’année que Rosine mène comme activité, la vente de condiments divers à son domicile. C’est à Houègbo dans le département de l’Atlantique que Rosine achète ses produits. Rosine avait bénéficié antérieurement de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé et les a tous bien remboursés. Dans le but d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et d’élargir son champ d’activité, Rosine sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Rosine H. was born in 1978 and is married to Henri FADEGNON, a bricklayer/mason. The couple have three children, all of whom attend school. For the past six years, Rosine has lived in the Fidjrossè neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, with her husband and children. Rosine helps her husband support the needs of their family, thanks to revenues from her commercial activity. Rosine did not attend school. For the last 12 years, Rosine has been selling a variety of condiments (peppers, onion, fresh tomatoes, crushed peppers, etc) from her home. She purchases her products from the city of Houègbo in the Atlantic department. Rosine previously received two loans from ALIDé, both of which she reimbursed. In order to increase the stock of her materials and broaden her commercial activity, Rosine is asking for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments (peppers, onion, fresh tomatoes, crushed peppers, etc)

loans.name: Nadar Herman

texts.fr: N. Nadar Herman est né le 26 Septembre 1972 et est marié à DOSSOU Sophie, une revendeuse. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Herman s’est installé au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants. Le couple se partage ensemble les charges familiales. Herman n’a fait que l’école primaire. Depuis dix ans, Herman mène comme activité, la vente de produits de SOBEBRA (société béninoise de brasserie), ce qui lui permet de nourrir sa famille et de subvenir à ses besoins. Herman s’approvisionne dans les dépôts de SOBEBRA à Cotonou, et vend ses produits à son domicile. Herman a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, deux crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Herman désire augmenter ses stocks de produits et mieux faire face à la demande des clients. C’est pourquoi Herman sollicite un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Nadar Herman N. was born on 26 Septembre 1972 and is married to Sophie DOSSOU, a re-seller of clothes. The couple have two children, both of whom attend school. 12 years ago Herman settled in the Fidjrosse neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, where he lives with his wife and children. The couple share the family's expenses. Herman only attended primary school. For the last ten years, Herman has been selling SOBEBRA (Benin brewery organization) products (alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks), which provides him with revenue to feed his family and attend to their needs. Herman stocks up in the SOBEBRA warehouses in Cotonou, and sell the products from his home. Herman previously received two loans from ALIDé, both of which were repaid. In order to address the demands of his customers, Herman is asking for a third loan to increase the stock of products he offers.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks

loans.name: Maridéath

texts.fr: A. Maridéath est née en 1976 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à LANIYAN Inoussa, un tailleur, Maridéath est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Maridéath et sa famille vivent au quartier Agbokou à Porto-Novo, depuis douze ans. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Maridéath a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Maridéath vend des vêtements et des sous-vêtements au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. De façon secondaire, Maridéath vend également des vernis à ongles  et divers autres produits. Maridéath s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. Maridéath a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé et qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans le but d'accroître davantage son activité et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire, Maridéath sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième concours financier.
texts.en:
A. Maridéath was born in 1976 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. Married to LANIYAN Inoussa, a tailor, Maridéath is the mother of four children, all in school. Maridéath and her family have been living in the Agbokou neighborhood in Porto-Novo for 12 years. The couple share the various duties in supporting their family. Maridéath left her studies in secondary school. To support herself, Maridéath sells clothing and underclothes in the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Secondarily, Maridéath also sells nail polish and various other items. She buys her merchandise in Dantokpa, international market of Bénin, and also in Nigeria, a neighboring country. Maridéath has already received two loans from ALIDé which have been correctly reimbursed. Wishing to grow her business and further increase her turnover, Maridéath is presently requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of clothing, underclothing, and nail polish for resale

loans.name: Mansouratou

texts.fr: O. Mansouratou est née en 1980 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à YESSOUFOU Mohamed, un menuisier, Mansouratou est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Mansouratou s'est installée depuis cinq ans environs, au quartier Houinmè à Porto-Novo, où elle réside avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Mansouratou a très peu fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Mansouratou vend divers produits de soins (savons, détergeants, dentifrices, brosses à dent, etc.) et des produits cosmétiques au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Mansouratou s'approvisionne. Mansouratou est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui avait obtenu trois prêts et qui ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Mansouratou désire rehausser davantage le niveau de son activité et se faire plus de revenus. C'est donc pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle que Mansouratou sollicite un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
O. Mansouratou was born in 1980 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. Married to YESSOUFOU Mohamed, a carpenter, Mansouratou is the mother of two children, both enrolled in school. She came to live about five years ago in the Houinmè neighborhood in Porto-Novo, where she presently resides with her husband and children. The couple share in supporting the family. Mansouratou scarcely attended school. To support herself, Mansouratou sells various personal care products (soap, detergent, toothpaste, toothbrushes, etc.) and cosmetics at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She buys her merchandise in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin, and also in Nigeria, a neighboring country. Mansouratou has been a client of ALIDé for a long time and has received three loans which she has correctly reimbursed. In view of the rising demand from her clientele, Mansouratou would like to expand her business and make more income. Thus, it is with the desire to satisfy her clientele that Mansouratou is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cosmetics and personal care products

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
Adama is a devoted, serious and very determined businesswoman. She owns a business centre at the central main market in Makeni and is married to a businessman who is a partner in her business. Adama has a child and dependents who are her relatives.

Adama started her foodstuffs business five years ago, her initial capital being provided by her husband. She goes to work at 7:00 a.m. and returns home at 6:40 p.m. Her provisions shop attracts many families who buy provisions for their homes.

Since the wholesale prices of goods increases frequently and transportation costs are very high, Adama needs a loan to help her buy stock in larger quantities so that changes in price do not immediately affect her business.

Adama’s challenge is how to make enough money from her business to help her husband support the home while continuing to invest in her business so as to be able to meet the cost of sending her child to university. Also, she is looking forward to buying a piece of land for erecting their own family house.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her stall

loans.name: Joséphine

texts.fr: Madame Joséphine  K. habite a la cite Biagui, une des cites environnantes, situe  non loin de la localité de Guediawaye. Elle s’active dans le secteur du commerce  plus particulièrement  dans la vente de prêt à porter car elle est couturière  de profession.  Elle évolue  aussi dans le tricotage et les crochets de pagnes tissés. Elle s’adonne aussi à la vente d’huile de palme. C’est durant les périodes fêtes que son activité  est plus rentable. Elle a pris l’option de choisir  ces différentes  activités dans le but de ne  pas rester oisive et d’avoir la possibilité  d’aider souvent ses enfants. Madame K. est mariée  et mère  de 3 enfants. Elle sollicite un crédit  de 150 000 frs dans l’objectif  d’investir dans la confection de chaussures. L’acquisition de ce financement lui permettra de diversifier ses produits de vente et par conséquent  d’accroitre le niveau de son épargne.
texts.en:
Mrs. Joséphine K. lives in the suburb of Biagui, situated not from from the town of Guediawaye. She is a merchant selling ready-to-wear, which is appropriate since she is a trained seamstress. She is also getting into knitwear and crocheted goods made of braided African print cloth. She also sells palm oil. Her business brings in the most money during holiday periods. She decided to choose these varied business activities so that she will not be without work and can often help her children. Mrs. K. is married and the mother of three children. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs with the intention of investing in shoe-making. The acquisition of this loan will permit her to further diversify the products she sells and thus grow her savings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: investing in a new business activity

loans.name: Kossi Sena

texts.fr: kossi sena A. a ouvert son restaurant en 2005, il a appelé son bar : «la volonté », il vend aussi des boissons à ses clients. Il est célibataire et c’est pour pouvoir assumer  ses charges qu’il s’est lancé dans ce commerce. Les produits nécessaires à l’activité de restauration sont épuisés, raison pour laquelle il sollicite chez WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 2 sacs de riz, 2 bidons d’huile et des casiers de boissons. Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes.
texts.en:
Kossi Sena A. opened his restaurant in 2005. He called the bar "la volonté” (the will). He also sells beverages to his customers. He is single and started this business to support himself. The supplies needed to run the restaurant are now depleted, which is why he is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy two bags of rice, two cans of oil, and cases of beverages. His clientele is diverse.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general food products

loans.name: Mary Njeri

texts.en:
Mary Njeri is a lady of 40 years who is married to Moses Chege. Together, they have four children aged between 6 and 20 years.

Mary is a farmer who deals in both vegetables and animal farming. She then sells the produce from her greengrocery shop to her customers who are residents of the area and also sells milk to her local cooperative society. Out of these businesses she is able to make Kshs 30,000 every month as profits.

Mary joined KADET after a marketing initiative in her area. She joined others and they formed a group and now she has applied for her first loan which she plans to use to buy animal feeds for her dairy cattle.

Mary would like, in future, to educate all her children to university level and buy her own piece of land which she will use to build a modern house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase animal feeds for her dairy cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Koffitsè Akuto

texts.fr: A. koffitsè est un homme très dynamique, en 2008,il s’est lancé dans le commerce de produits d’alimention générale qui est un commerce très souvent exercé par les femmes. Il attire beaucoup de clients car il a une manière très conviviale de les acceuillir. Pour satisfaire la demande de ses clients il doit se réapprovisionner c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite de WAGES un crédit afin de s’acheter 4 cartons de tomates, 4 sacs de riz, 4 cartons de spaghetti, 4 bidons d’huile d’arachide.  Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes.
texts.en:
Koffitsé A. is a very dynamic man, in 2008, he took up the commerce of food products which is a business often performed by women. He attracts many customers because he has a very friendly way of welcoming them. To satisfy the demand of his clientele he needs to renew his stock which is why he is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy 4 boxes of tomatoes,4 sacks of rice,4 boxes of spaghetti and 4 cans of peanut oil. His clients come from all circumstances.

Translated from French by Barbara Belli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of everyday food products

loans.name: Hawa

texts.fr: Madame Hawa M. est une institutrice de 39 ans qui habite à Daroukhane à Guediawaye. Elle fréquente  depuis plus de 3 ans l’école  Diambar  à Baye Laye. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse de Baye Laye depuis mars 2004. Pendant les périodes  de vacance elle s’adonne aux activités  commerciales. Elle gère  une boutique  à son domicile qui est supervisée par sa fille pendant l’année  scolaire. Elle commercialise des denrées  alimentaires et autres produits divers. Elle sollicite un crédit  de 150 000 frs pour renforcer sa boutique en produits pour mieux rentabiliser son activité. Les bénéfices générés lui permettront d’aider son mari à supporter les charges de la famille et plus particulièrement d’assurer la scolarité de ses enfants .Elle est mère  de 6 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 1 et 18 ans.
texts.en:
Ms. Hawa M. is a 39-year-old teacher who lives in Daroukhane, in Guediawaye. She attended the Diambar School in Baye Laye for three years. She has been an associate of the Baye Laye credit association since March 2004. During vacation periods, she devotes herself to commercial work. She manages a store in her home that is supervised by her daughter during the school year. She sells foodstuffs and a variety of other goods. Hawa is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs for bolstering her store with goods in order to make her business more profitable. The profits generated will enable her to help her husband to support the family and especially to ensure her children's education. Hawa is the mother of six children, ranging from 1 to 18 years of age.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her working capital

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: A. afi exerce  comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis 8 ans déjà et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Son stock de marchandises est en baisse, raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 1 bidon de boisson sodabi, 3 sacs de riz, 15 plateaux d’œuf, 3 bidons d’huile  des cartes de recharge et divers produits d’alimentation générale. Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
A. Afi has a revenue-generating business involving grocery items. She has been in this business for eight years already. She gets her supplies at the big market of Lomé. Her inventory of merchandise is low, so she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a container of sodabi (a distilled liquor), 3 sacks of rice, 15 trays of eggs, 3 containers of oil, some phone recharge cards, and a variety of grocery items. She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana S. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Juana is 39 years old and is married to a husband that is a peasant. She has two children who both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bigger charcoal store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sima

texts.fr:
En 2007 S. sima s’est lancée dans le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale , elle s’approvisionne dans divers marchés locaux de lomé. Elle est en rupture de stock et veut s’approvisionner pour  pouvoir rehausser son stock et ses ventes. elle sollicite un crédit pour l’achat de 4 cartons de savons BF, 6 cartons de savons popular, 5cartons de RAD liquide, 6 cartons de sardines, 3 cartons de couscous sipa, 4 cartons de sucre et 4 cartons de mayonnaise jago
Elle est célibataire et c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’elle assume ses propres charges
texts.en:
In 2007, S. Sima embarked on a business involving groceries. She gets her supplies from various local markets in Lomé. She is low on stock and wants to stock up again to be able to enhance her inventory and her sales. She is requesting a loan for buying 4 boxes of BF soaps, 6 boxes of popular soaps, 5 boxes of liquid RAD, 6 boxes of sardines, 3 boxes of SIPA couscous, 4 boxes of sugar, and 4 boxes of Jago mayonnaise. Sima is unmarried, and with the revenues from her business, she supports herself.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Suzi

texts.en:
Suzi  P. is currently in the business of selling sweet potatoes and cassava tubers at the market and is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell.  Suzi is 41 years old and is married to a husband that is a peasant. She has three children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to improve her house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more inventory

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Deborah A. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to sell.  Deborah is 38 years old and is married to a husband who is a police man. She has two children who both attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: El Haddji Djibril

texts.fr: Monsieur El Hadji Djibril C. est un jeune électricien  de 30 ans qui habite à Whakhinane a Guediawaye. Il a vécu  15 années de dur  apprentissage. Il  est membre de la caisse de Baye Laye depuis aout 2006. Actuellement il a note un ralentissement de son activité  et c’est la raison pour laquelle il sollicite un crédit  de 100 000 frs pour démarrer  une activité  de commerce qui lui permettra de gérer  les périodes  de non fonctionnement  de sa profession. Il est célibataire, mais les revenus qui seront générés par son activité  lui permettront d’assister ses parents et aussi de se prendre en charge financièrement. Il a aussi l’intention de développer  son épargne.
texts.en:
Mr. El Hadji Djibril C., aged 30, is a young electrician who lives in Whakhinane, in Guediawaye. He has fifteen hard years of experience in an apprenticeship. He has been a member of the Baye Laye credit association since April 2006. At present, he has noticed a slowdown in business, and this is the reason for his request for a loan of 100,000 francs in order to start up a business that will enable him to manage when his work is slow. He is unmarried, but the revenues that will be generated from his business will allow him to help his parents and also to support himself financially. He also intends to develop his savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en:
Sunday G. is currently in the business of selling weaving materials and treating hair at the beauty salon and is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials.  Sunday is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has one child who does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more hair weaving materials

loans.name: Monique

texts.fr:
Jeune femme de 46 ans,celibataire avec 3 enfants dont l'age varie entre 30 et 24 ans,il ya 20 ans deja qu'elle a ouvert ce petit  restaurant ,elle prepare des plats locaux,comme le sakasaka, fait a base de feuille de maniocs, 3 pieces, un melange de poisson fume ou sale fait avec de coco(genre de legumes de la foret congolaise) et de la pate d'arachide et a cela elle ajoute des  grillades de cuisses ou ailes de poulets et des brochettes.Ses recettes journalieres sont de 25000 a 50.000frs
Comme le restaurant est situe entre un marche et non loin de la gare routiere , ses potentiels clients sont les voyageurs et vendeurs du marche

Avec l'octroi du pret , une partie elle compte faire des provisions en gros comme cartons de cuisses et ailes de poulets,condiments pour assaisonner , des bidons d'huile,des sacs d'oignons et d'ailes et des bidons d'huiles et l'autre partie, elle pense a repeindre son restaurant,et renouveller le stock des nappes de tables et torchons
Pour l'avenir elle pense a ouvrir un grand restaurant et epargner pour qu'a la fin elle construise une maison pour sa famille
texts.en:
This young woman of 46, single, with three children whose ages vary from 30 to 24, opened a little restaurant 20 years ago. She prepares local dishes like 'sakasaka', made with manioc leaves; three parts, a mixture of smoked or salted fish with 'coco' (a kind of vegetable from the Conglese forest) and peanut butter. To that she adds grilled chicken thighs or wings and meat on a spit. Her daily receipts are from 25,000 to 50,000 francs. As her restaurant is situated in a marketplace and not far from the bus station, her potential customers are travelers and market sales people. With the loan, she intends to buy some provisions wholesale such as cartons of chicken wings and thighs, condiments to season her dishes, tins of cooking oil, sacks of onions and garlic. Also, she is thinking about repainting her restaurant and getting new tablecloths and dish towels. In future, she is thinking about opening a big restaurant and putting aside savings so that she can build a house for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of provisions such as cartons of meat, chicken thighs and wings, condiments for seasoning, and a tin of oil

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia C. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize and millet at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of groundnuts and dried cassava to sell.
